Treatment Methods (Human-Friendly Guide): This kills young seedlings in the nursery. Treat seeds with Trichoderma viride (4g/kg) before sowing. Avoid over-watering the nursery bed; the soil should not be soggy. If you see rotting, drench the soil with Copper Oxychloride (3g/liter). Use raised beds to help excess water drain away.

Look for brown spots with rings on older leaves. Spray Mancozeb (2g/liter) or Chlorothalonil (2g/liter) early in the morning. Remove and burn infected lower leaves to stop the upward spread. Rotate crops—do not plant tomatoes where you just grew potatoes or brinjals.

A fast-spreading rot during cloudy, wet weather. Spray Metalaxyl + Mancozeb (2g/liter) or Cymoxanil (2g/liter) immediately at the first sign. Keep the field clean and avoid overhead sprinklers that wet the leaves. If it rains heavily, re-spray after the rain stops.

The plant yellows and dries up from one side. The fungus lives in the soil, so chemical sprays don't work well. Drench the soil around roots with Copper Oxychloride (3g/liter). The best fix is prevention: mix Trichoderma bio-fungicide with manure before planting and use resistant seeds.

Small round spots with grey centers on lower leaves. Remove infected leaves by hand to lower the fungal load. Spray Copper Oxychloride (3g/liter) or Mancozeb (2.5g/liter). Ensure good spacing between plants so air can flow through; crowded plants trap humidity and make this worse.

This causes sunken, water-soaked spots on ripe fruit. It often happens when fruits touch the soil. Harvest fruit as soon as it ripens; do not leave it on the plant too long. Mulching (covering soil with straw/plastic) helps prevent soil spores from splashing onto the fruit. Spray Chlorothalonil (2g/liter) if severe.

You will see a white, powdery coating on leaves, looking like flour. It happens in dry, warm weather. Spray wettable Sulfur (3g/liter) or Karathane (1ml/liter). A home remedy is spraying a mixture of milk and water (1:9 ratio) or baking soda solution, which changes the leaf surface pH.

Brown and grey rings appear on fruit touching the wet ground. It looks like a "buck's eye." Stake your plants to keep fruits off the soil. Mulching is the best prevention. Avoid flood irrigation that keeps the soil surface wet for too long. If needed, spray Copper Oxychloride.

The plant droops and dies suddenly while still green. There is no chemical cure. Use wilt-resistant varieties (like Arka Abha). Dip seedling roots in Pseudomonas fluorescens before planting. Rotate crops with paddy (rice) or marigold to naturally clean the soil of bacteria.

Small, dark, greasy spots appear on leaves and fruits. It spreads by splashing rain. Avoid overhead watering. Spray Streptocycline (1g in 10 liters water) mixed with Copper Oxychloride (30g in 10 liters). Do not work in the field when plants are wet, as you will carry the bacteria to healthy plants.

Leaves turn brown at the edges ("firing") and stems may split open. Fruit may have small "bird-eye" spots. Use disease-free seeds from trusted sources. Sterilize your pruning tools (knives/scissors) with bleach solution between plants. Remove and destroy infected plants immediately to save the rest.

Leaves curl upward and plants remain small. Spread by whiteflies. There is no cure for the virus. Pull out and bury infected plants instantly. Control whiteflies using yellow sticky traps (15/acre) and spray Imidacloprid (0.5ml/liter) or Neem oil to stop the spread.

Causes bronzing of young leaves and ring-spots on fruit. Spread by tiny insects called Thrips. Control Thrips using blue sticky traps and by spraying Fipronil or Spinosad. Keep the field borders free of weeds where thrips hide. Remove infected plants immediately.

Leaves show a light and dark green mosaic pattern. This is highly contagious and spreads by touch (smokers can spread it from tobacco!). Wash hands with soap before handling plants. Do not smoke near the field. Remove infected plants and do not compost them.

The bottom of the fruit turns black and flat. This is not a disease but a Calcium deficiency caused by uneven watering. Water regularly so the soil stays moist (not soaked). Spray Calcium Chloride (2g/liter) on the fruits when they are small (marble size).

cracks appear on the fruit skin. This happens when heavy rain follows a dry spell; the fruit drinks water too fast and bursts. maintain consistent soil moisture by watering regularly. Harvest fruits before heavy rains if they are close to ripening.

White/yellow patches on the fruit where the sun hit it too hard. This happens when leaves fall off due to other diseases. Keep the plant healthy so leaves cover the fruit. In severe summers, you can use shade nets or cover fruit clusters with straw.

Fruit becomes deformed and scarred. Caused by cold weather during flowering or high nitrogen fertilizer. Avoid planting too early in winter. Use balanced fertilizers; do not overuse Urea (Nitrogen) which causes rapid, weak growth.

Plants look weak and stunted; roots have swollen "knots" or galls. Plant African Marigold flowers between tomato rows (their roots release chemicals that repel nematodes). Apply Neem Cake (250kg/acre) to the soil. Use Paecilomyces lilacinus (bio-agent) in the soil.

A grey, fuzzy mold grows on dying flowers or fruit stem ends. It loves high humidity. The best treatment is airflow—prune extra leaves and keep spacing wide. Remove dead flowers that stick to the fruit. Spray Chlorothalonil only if necessary.

A white mold grows on the stem near the soil, looking like mustard seeds. The plant wilts quickly. Deep plow the field in summer to bury the fungus. Solarise soil (cover with plastic in summer). Drench the base of plants with Trichoderma.

Pale yellow spots on top of leaves, with olive-green mold underneath. Common in humid greenhouses. Improve ventilation immediately to lower humidity. Use drip irrigation instead of overhead sprays. Spray Copper-based fungicides if the infection spreads.

Spray Lambda-cyhalothrin or Monocrotophos early in the morning or late evening when the insects are active. Ensure proper spray coverage on new shoots, leaves, and nuts. If the attack continues, repeat the spray after 15–20 days. Do not spray during hot noon hours. Regular spraying at the correct time helps reduce heavy crop loss caused by this pest.

Inspect trees every month. If gum or sawdust is seen on the trunk, remove the bark near the spot and pull out the white worm inside. Kill the worm immediately. Clean the hole and fill it with Chlorpyriphos solution or Carbaryl paste. This treatment must be done carefully to save the tree from dying.

Spray Bordeaux mixture (1%) or Copper Oxychloride when new reddish leaves start appearing. If rain occurs during flowering, spray again to protect flowers and young nuts. This treatment prevents flowers from drying and falling. Timely spraying during cloudy and rainy weather is very important to avoid heavy yield loss.

Cut infected branches at least 30 cm below the affected area and burn them immediately. Apply Bordeaux paste on the cut ends to stop further infection. After pruning, spray Copper Oxychloride on nearby branches. This treatment should be completed before the monsoon season to prevent the disease from spreading to healthy branches.

Cut dried branch tips well below the dead portion until healthy green wood is seen. Apply Bordeaux paste on all cut surfaces to protect them. Proper pruning and sealing of cuts help stop the disease from moving downward. Timely cutting saves the tree and prevents further drying of branches.

Gently scrape out the gum from the affected bark area. After cleaning, apply Bordeaux paste or Copper Oxychloride on the wound. Ensure the treatment covers the entire affected portion. This helps stop further gum flow and prevents infection from spreading inside the trunk.

In young plants or nursery seedlings with heavy damage, spray Neem oil or Quinalphos once. Ensure spraying is done properly on fresh leaves. Usually one spray is enough. Avoid repeated chemical sprays, as this pest often reduces naturally once the plant grows stronger.

First spray Neem oil to control insects causing sticky deposits. Then spray starch solution (maida kanji) on leaves. The black layer will dry, crack, and fall off naturally. One or two sprays are sufficient. This treatment helps leaves regain normal color and function.

Spray Bordeaux mixture or Copper Oxychloride if infection is severe. Ensure full coverage of affected leaves. One proper spray is usually enough. This treatment controls the algae and helps leaves recover. Regular monitoring helps avoid repeated infection.

Dust fine Sulphur powder or spray Wettable Sulphur early in the morning when white powder appears on flowers or leaves. One timely spray protects flowers from drying and falling. Early treatment during cool weather helps ensure better nut setting and yield.

Collect and destroy all damaged apples and nuts immediately. Spray Spinosad or Profenophos once when fruits are small, about pea size. Proper timing of spray kills young worms before they enter fruits. This treatment helps reduce fruit damage and yield loss.

If thrips attack is heavy during flowering, spray Thiamethoxam or Fipronil once. Spray should be light and well-directed on tender parts. Avoid unnecessary repeat sprays. Correct timing helps protect flowers and improves nut formation.

Spray Mancozeb (2 g per litre of water) or Copper Oxychloride on affected plants. One or two sprays at 10–15 day intervals are enough. This treatment is mainly needed for young plants and nursery seedlings to prevent leaf damage.

Spray Bordeaux mixture (1%) just before the start of heavy monsoon rains. One preventive spray protects tender shoots from rotting and reduces leaf fall. Proper timing of this spray is very important to protect the crop during continuous rainy periods.

Put pheromone traps (5 per acre) to catch adult moths early. Check flowers often and remove rosette flowers and destroy them. If worms increase, spray Profenophos or Emamectin Benzoate as advised. Do not delay spraying once worms enter bolls. After harvest, allow sheep grazing or deep ploughing to kill worms left in the soil.

Grow marigold or cowpea around the field to attract worms away from cotton. Fix bird perches so birds eat caterpillars. If worms increase, spray Spinosad or Indoxacarb. Do not use the same pesticide repeatedly. Timely spraying saves flowers and bolls from damage.

Treat seeds with Streptocycline before sowing. If disease appears, spray Copper Oxychloride (3 g per litre) mixed with Streptocycline (1 g per 10 litres). Spray again after rain if needed. Avoid sprinkler irrigation. After harvest, collect and destroy old cotton plants to stop disease spread.

There is no medicine to cure this virus. Control whitefly, which spreads it. Use yellow sticky traps and spray Neem oil or Diafenthiuron when whiteflies increase. Always grow virus-resistant cotton varieties. Remove infected plants early to protect healthy ones nearby.

Treat seeds with Imidacloprid for early protection. If pests appear later, spray Acetamiprid or Flonicamid. Use yellow sticky traps to reduce insects. Avoid unnecessary spraying when helpful insects are present. Correct spraying at the right time prevents leaf curling and yield loss.

Spray Neem oil, Spiromesifen, or Pyriproxyfen when whiteflies increase. Always spray on the lower side of leaves, where they hide. Do not use too much urea fertilizer. Keep field borders free from weeds. Proper control prevents virus spread and black leaf coating.

First destroy ant nests, as ants protect mealybugs. Spray Profenophos or Buprofezin directly on white cotton-like insects. For small attack, wash insects with strong water spray. If attack is heavy, remove and burn infected plants immediately to stop spreading.

Spray Mancozeb (2.5 g per litre) or Propiconazole (1 ml per litre) when brown spots appear. Repeat after 10–15 days if needed. Apply enough potash fertilizer. Remove fallen infected leaves from the field to reduce disease spread.

When white powder appears on leaves, spray Wettable Sulphur (3 g per litre) or Carbendazim. One or two sprays are usually enough. Early spraying prevents leaf fall and helps proper boll formation at later crop stages.

Treat seeds with Trichoderma before sowing. If affected patches appear, drench soil around them with Copper Oxychloride. Improve drainage and avoid water stagnation. Early prevention is very important, as infected plants cannot be saved later.

Use wilt-resistant cotton varieties. Mix Trichoderma with compost and apply to soil during planting. Follow crop rotation with maize or jowar. These methods reduce fungus in soil and protect future crops.

Remove excess water immediately after heavy rain or irrigation. Spray 2% urea or DAP solution on leaves to help plants recover. If available, drench roots with Cobalt Chloride. Proper water management prevents further plant damage.

Do earthing up around the base of plants to stop egg laying. Drench the stem base with Chlorpyriphos. After harvest, remove and burn cotton stalks to kill hidden insects. This reduces next season’s attack.

Crush egg masses seen on leaves. Install pheromone traps. If caterpillars increase, spray Novaluron or Thiodicarb. Use poison bait (rice bran + jaggery + pesticide) in the evening. Early control prevents heavy leaf damage.

This is the most dangerous disease. You will see yellow, angular spots on the top of leaves and a violet/grey fuzz underneath. It spreads fast in wet weather. Spray Metalaxyl + Mancozeb (2.5g/liter) or Cymoxanil immediately. Don't water from overhead; keep leaves dry. If not treated, the plant will burn up quickly.

Look for white, flour-like powder on leaves and stems. It usually happens in dry, warm weather. Spray wettable Sulphur (2g/liter) or Karathane. A home remedy is to spray a mix of baking soda and water, or diluted milk (1 part milk, 9 parts water). Remove leaves that are heavily coated.

Leaves become mottled (mix of light and dark green), wrinkled, and misshapen. Fruits become bumpy and bitter. There is no medicine for this virus. Remove and bury infected plants immediately. Control the Aphids that spread it by using yellow sticky traps and spraying Neem oil or Imidacloprid.

This fly lays eggs inside the fruit. The maggots eat the inside, causing the fruit to rot and drop. This is a major headache for farmers. Use "Pheromone Traps" (fruit fly lures) to catch male flies (4-6 traps per acre). Collect and bury all fallen fruits deep in the soil so maggots don't survive. You can also spray Neem oil to repel them.

You will see reddish-brown spots on leaves and sunken, slimy salmon-pink spots on the fruit. This happens often in warm, rainy weather. Treat seeds with Carbendazim before planting. If you see spots, spray Chlorothalonil or Mancozeb (2.5g/liter). Rotate crops—don't plant cucumber in the same spot every season.

Small, water-soaked spots appear on leaves that look square or angular (because veins stop them). The dead tissue falls out, leaving "shot holes." Avoid overhead sprinklers. Spray Copper Oxychloride (2.5g/liter) or Streptocycline to stop this bacteria. Don't work in the field when plants are wet.

The plant turns yellow and wilts slowly, usually starting from older leaves. If you cut the stem near the soil, you see brown streaks inside. Use resistant seeds. Drench the soil with Trichoderma viride (bio-fungicide) or Carbendazim. This fungus stays in soil for years, so rotate with crops like corn or spinach.

The stem turns brown and may split, oozing a gummy, amber-colored sticky fluid. Leaves may develop large brown spots. Spray Mancozeb or Chlorothalonil. Improve air circulation by pruning extra vines. Avoid wetting the stems while watering. Clean up all plant debris after harvest.

Plants look weak, stunted, and yellow, even if you water them well. If you pull up the roots, they have swollen knots or galls. Add plenty of Neem cake to the soil before planting. Plant Marigold flowers between rows to repel them. Solarize the soil (cover with plastic in summer) to kill them with heat.

Bright orange/red beetles eat holes in young leaves and flowers. The grubs (babies) eat the roots underground. Pick and kill beetles by hand in the early morning when they are sluggish. Dust wood ash on the leaves to repel them. If the attack is heavy, spray Chlorpyriphos or Malathion carefully.

Tiny insects that scrape the leaves, making them look silvery or bronze. They can also damage the fruit skin. Use blue sticky traps to catch them. Spray Fipronil or Spinosad if the population is high. Keep the field free of weeds where they like to hide.

Small green or black bugs cluster on the underside of leaves and suck sap. They leave a sticky residue (honeydew) that turns black (sooty mold). Spray simple soapy water or Neem oil first. If that doesn't work, use Imidacloprid. Ladybugs are friends—they eat aphids, so don't kill them!

You will see white, snake-like winding trails on the leaves. The maggot is inside the leaf eating its way through. Usually, you don't need heavy chemicals. Remove leaves with many trails. Spray Neem Seed Kernel Extract (NSKE 5%) to stop the adult fly from laying eggs.

This is the biggest threat in rainy/cloudy weather. Look for yellow "oil spots" on top of leaves and white fungal growth underneath. Spray Bordeaux mixture (1%) or Copper Oxychloride immediately. If the attack is severe, use systemic fungicides like Metalaxyl or Cymoxanil. Prune extra shoots to keep the canopy open so air flows through.

White, ash-like powder covers the leaves and berries. This happens in cool, dry weather. The berries may crack and rot. Dust Sulphur powder (20kg/acre) or spray Wettable Sulphur. If the infection is high, use fungicides like Hexaconazole or Myclobutanil. Keep the center of the vine open to sunlight.

You will see small brown spots with grey centers and red borders on leaves and berries (looks like a bird’s eye). It spreads fast in rain. Prune and burn infected twigs. Spray Copper Oxychloride or Thiophanate Methyl. Do this early when new shoots appear after pruning to protect the young growth.

White, cotton-like masses appear on stems and bunches. They suck sap and make the fruit sticky and black (sooty mold). Ants protect them, so kill ant nests first. Wash the vines with a strong water jet. Spray Buprofezin or Methomyl. Applying a sticky grease band around the main trunk stops them from climbing up.

These tiny insects scratch the berry skin, causing "corky" or scabby brown patches (scab). This destroys the market value of the fruit. Use blue sticky traps to monitor them. Spray Fipronil or Spinosad during the berry setting stage. Keep the vineyard weed-free.

This beetle eats the swelling buds just after pruning. If they eat the bud, you lose the whole bunch for that season. It is very dangerous. Identify them by the "shot holes" they make in leaves. Spray Phosalone or Quinalphos immediately after pruning if you see beetles. Loose bark on the trunk should be removed as they hide there.

Small water-soaked spots appear on leaves and stems, eventually drying up and cracking. It often strikes after heavy rain or hail. Spray Streptocycline (0.5g/liter) mixed with Copper Oxychloride. Avoid overhead sprinkling. Do not perform pruning or handling when the vines are wet.

The vine looks weak and leaves turn yellow. Look for holes in the main trunk with wood dust (sawdust) coming out. Clean the hole with a wire. Insert a cotton wick soaked in Dichlorvos or petrol into the hole and seal it with mud/clay. This kills the worm inside.

Leaves turn reddish-brown or bronze and look dusty. This happens in hot, dry weather. They spin fine webs on the underside of leaves. Spray Dicofol or Wettable Sulphur. Avoid using synthetic pyrethroids (like Cypermethrin) as they can actually make mite problems worse.

Fruits split open, usually after sudden rain near harvest. This is often due to irregular watering or Calcium deficiency. Maintain consistent soil moisture (don't let it get too dry then flood it). Spray Calcium Chloride and Boron during berry development to strengthen the skin.

Dark, canoe-shaped spots appear on the bottom of shoots. The cane may break easily. It weakens the vine over years. Prune out dead wood during the dormant season. Spray Mancozeb or Copper fungicides just as the buds are breaking (opening) to protect new growth.

This is the biggest new threat. The caterpillar hides inside the central funnel (whorl) and eats leaves, leaving lots of "sawdust" poop. It has a "Y" mark on its head. In early stages, spray Emamectin Benzoate or Spinetoram. You can also put wet sand or soil mixed with ash into the funnel to suffocate the worm.

The worm bores into the stem. You will see "pinholes" in lines on the leaves. If it attacks young plants, the central leaf dries up (Dead Heart). Apply Carbofuran granules (3-4 granules per plant) directly inside the leaf whorl/funnel. If spraying, use Chlorantraniliprole. Remove dead stalks from the field after harvest so they don't hide there.

Long, boat-shaped grey/brown spots appear on leaves. It looks like the leaf was burnt. It usually comes when the weather is cool and humid. Spray Mancozeb (2.5g/liter) or Zineb as soon as you see the spots. If the disease is severe, use Propiconazole. Plant resistant hybrids if this is common in your area.

You will see small, powdery brown bumps (pustules) on both sides of the leaves. It looks like rust on iron. This happens in cool, wet weather. Usually, Indian maize is tough enough to handle this, but if the infection is very high, spray Mancozeb (2g/liter) or Wettable Sulphur to stop it from spreading.

Leaves develop yellow/white stripes and look velvety underneath. In severe cases, the tassel (flower) becomes leafy and deformed ("Crazy Top"). This starts from the soil or seeds. Treat seeds with Metalaxyl before sowing (6g/kg). Remove and bury infected plants immediately. Do not plant maize in the same field year after year.

The plant stalks become weak and rot near the ground, often falling over. If you split the stalk, the inside looks black and dusty like charcoal. This happens when the weather is very hot and dry after flowering. The best prevention is regular irrigation—don't let the soil crack from dryness. Use Trichoderma in the soil.

This attacks very young seedlings (up to 2 weeks old). The central leaf wilts and dries up. It is worse if you plant late. Treat seeds with Imidacloprid (10ml/kg) before sowing. Use a higher seed rate (plant extra seeds) so you can pull out the damaged ones and still have a full field.

They eat the roots and base of the stem, and the plant falls over. This is common in dry, sandy red soils. Mix Chlorpyriphos or Fipronil dust in the soil before planting. If the standing crop is attacked, drench the soil with Chlorpyriphos (4ml/liter of water) near the plant base. Avoid using raw (undecomposed) farmyard manure.

You will see large, dirty-colored spots with bands on the leaves and the sheath (the part of the leaf hugging the stem). It spreads from the ground up. Remove the lower leaves that touch the ground. Spray Propiconazole or Hexaconazole if the disease moves up towards the corn cob.

Small, diamond-shaped or rectangular yellow-brown spots appear on leaves. The spots may merge and kill the whole leaf. It is common in warm, wet areas. Spray Mancozeb (2.5g/liter) or Dithane M-45. Crop rotation helps because the fungus survives on old corn trash in the field.

You will see rough, brown, raised corky spots on leaves and fruit. It spreads fast in wet weather. Prune and burn infected twigs first. Spray Copper Oxychloride (3g/liter) mixed with Streptocycline (1g in 10 liters). Since this is bacterial, adding the antibiotic (Streptocycline) is very important. To prevent it, plant windbreaks (tall trees) around the orchard to stop wind-blown bacteria.

Dark gum oozes from the trunk near the ground, and the bark rots. This happens if the soil is too wet. Scrape the infected bark with a sharp knife until you reach healthy wood. Apply Bordeaux Paste on the wound. Drench the soil around the roots with Metalaxyl or Copper Oxychloride. Ensure water does not touch the main trunk during irrigation (use the double-ring method).

Leaves show yellow mottling (patches of yellow and green), and fruits stay small, green, and bitter. This is spread by a tiny insect called Psylla. There is no cure for the disease itself. You must cut down infected trees to save the rest. Control the Psylla insect by spraying Imidacloprid or Dimethoate regularly.

Branches start drying from the tip downwards (like a burning candle). Leaves fall off and the tree looks thin. This is often due to poor nutrition or root problems. Prune the dead branches 2–3 inches into the healthy green wood. Apply Copper Oxychloride paste on cut ends. Feed the tree well with fertilizers and micronutrients (Zinc/Boron) to boost its strength.

You will see shiny, silvery zig-zag trails on young leaves. The leaves curl and look ugly. This attacks the tender new growth (flush). Spray Neem oil (10ml/liter) or Imidacloprid as soon as new leaves appear. Since the worm is inside the leaf, simple contact poisons don't work well; systemic medicines are better.

This moth pierces ripe fruit at night to drink juice. The fruit rots and falls after a few days. Insecticides don't work well because the moth flies away. The best solution is to destroy fallen rotting fruits daily so they don't attract more moths. You can also hang poison baits (jaggery water + pesticide) in the orchard.

A small louse that sits on new buds. It spreads the deadly Greening disease. If you see them, spray Monocrotophos or Thiamethoxam immediately. Pruning the orchard to keep it open and airy helps reduce their population. Protecting new flush (new leaves) is the most critical time to spray.

Black or green bugs cluster on the underside of tender leaves and suck sap. They leave sticky honeydew which turns into black soot (Sooty Mold). They also spread the Tristeza Virus. Spray Dimethoate or soapy water. Ladybugs eat them, so try to use milder sprays like Neem oil first to save the friendly insects.

White powder appears on young leaves and small fruits. The leaves may twist and fall. This happens in cool, dry mornings. Spray Wettable Sulphur (3g/liter) or Karathane. Removing water shoots (fast-growing weak branches) helps air circulation and reduces this disease.

For small gardens, simply hand-pick the caterpillars. Note: The young ones look exactly like bird droppings, while older ones are bright green. If the infestation is high, spray Bacillus thuringiensis (Bt) at 2g/liter or Neem oil (5ml/liter) for a natural cure. For severe attacks in large orchards, spray Quinalphos or Chlorpyriphos. Check new leaves often during monsoon, as they can eat all the leaves in just a few days.

This causes "burnt" spots on leaves or broken "necks." To treat, spray Tricyclazole (0.6g/liter) or Carbendazim (1g/liter). Avoid using too much Urea, which makes plants weak. Treat seeds with Pseudomonas fluorescens (10g/kg) before sowing. If "Neck Blast" appears during the grain stage, spray immediately to save your yield and prevent empty grains.

Small, oval brown spots appear on leaves, often in weak soil. Fix this by improving soil health with balanced fertilizers (NPK) and Zinc. If the infection is heavy, spray Mancozeb (2g/liter) or Edifenphos (1ml/liter). Soaking seeds in hot water (52°C) for 10 minutes before planting can kill hidden spores. It is often a "disease of the poor soil," so good manuring helps prevent it.

This causes long, wavy yellow-white streaks from leaf tips. It spreads fast in wind and rain. There is no easy cure, but spraying Streptocycline (1g in 10L) mixed with Copper Oxychloride (20g) helps slow it down. Reduce Nitrogen levels and drain the field for a few days to stop bacteria from moving through the water to healthy plants.

Look for greenish-grey "snake-skin" patches on leaf sheaths near the water line. It loves crowded, wet fields. To treat, spray Hexaconazole (2ml/liter) or Validamycin (2ml/liter) directly at the base of plants where the stem meets the water. Keep the field free of weeds and avoid planting too closely; wider spacing allows air to dry out the dampness.

Grains turn into large, velvety orange-to-black "smut balls" during flowering in cool, rainy weather. Once balls appear, they cannot be cured. Prevention is key: spray Copper Oxychloride (2.5g/liter) or Propiconazole (1ml/liter) during the "booting" stage (just before grain-heads emerge). Remove and burn any smut balls seen to prevent the fungus from staying in the soil.

This rots the leaf sheath covering the young grain-head, stopping it from coming out fully. It usually happens when insects wound the plant. Spray Carbendazim (1g/liter) or Mancozeb (2g/liter) at the "booting" stage. Controlling stem borers and other insects is vital, as their bites create the entry points for this fungus to infect the plant from inside.

Plants turn orange-yellow and stop growing (stunted). This virus is spread by Green Leafhoppers. You cannot treat the virus itself, so you must kill the insects. Spray Imidacloprid (0.5ml/liter) or Thiamethoxam immediately. Pull out and bury infected yellow plants instantly. Using resistant varieties like Vikramarya is the most effective way to avoid this disease entirely.

Some plants grow much taller and thinner than others, eventually turning pale and dying. This is a seed-borne disease. The best treatment is seed soaking: treat seeds with Carbendazim (2g/kg) before sowing. If you see these "foolish" tall seedlings in the field, pull them out carefully and destroy them so they don’t spread the fungus into the soil for next year.

Small black spots appear on the leaf sheath at the water level; later, the stem rots and the plant falls over. Draining the water and letting the soil crack for a few days can stop the fungus from spreading. Apply extra Potassium (Potash) to strengthen the stem walls. If severe, drench the base of plants with Thiophanate-methyl (1g/liter) to protect the stem.

Grains turn black, red, or dark brown, making them look dirty and reducing market price. This is caused by various germs attacking during the "milky" stage. To prevent this, spray a combination of Mancozeb and Carbendazim (2g/liter) when grains are just forming. Ensure the field is free of weeds, as they act as a home for these germs between seasons.

This is a nutritional problem, not a germ. Spray Zinc Sulphate (5g) mixed with Lime (2.5g) in 1 liter of water as soon as you see dusty brown spots. For a 1-acre field, use 2kg Zinc Sulphate with 1kg Lime in 400 liters of water. For future crops, apply Zinc Sulphate (25kg per hectare) directly into the soil during land preparation.

This appears as fine, transparent streaks between leaf veins. Spray Streptocycline (1g in 10L) mixed with Copper Oxychloride (20g). Avoid excess Nitrogen, which makes leaves soft and easy to infect. Keep water levels low and avoid moving through the field while plants are wet to prevent spreading the bacteria on your clothes or tools to healthy areas.

You will see thin, short brown lines on the leaves. It usually happens in soils lacking Potassium. To treat, spray Propiconazole (1ml/liter) or Mancozeb (2g/liter) at the booting stage. The best long-term solution is to ensure you apply enough Muriate of Potash (MOP) during the early stages of the crop to make the plants naturally resistant.

Caused by tiny worms in the soil. Apply Carbofuran 3G granules (10-12 kg per acre) into the standing water. After harvesting, burn the left-over stubble or plow the field deeply during summer to kill the worms hiding in the soil. Rotating your crop with non-cereal plants like pulses for one season will starve the worms and clean the field naturally.

The grain-head comes out looking like a thin, silvery-white "candle" instead of grains. This lives inside the seed, so treat seeds with hot water (52°C) or Carbendazim (2g/kg) before planting. If you see "candle" heads in the field, pull them out carefully and bury them immediately so the black powder doesn't blow onto healthy plants or infect the soil.

Leaf tips look bleached or "scalded" with brown wavy bands. Spray Carbendazim (1g/liter) at the first sign. Avoid heavy Nitrogen doses, especially in the rainy season. Ensure enough space between plants for air to flow; crowded plants stay wet longer, which helps this fungus spread. Proper drainage and balanced nutrition are the best ways to keep the leaves healthy.

A few grains turn into a black, powdery mass. It is hard to "cure" once visible. Prevent it by treating seeds with Carboxin or Carbendazim (2g/kg) before sowing. Spraying Propiconazole (1ml/liter) when the "boot" leaf is visible protects emerging grains. Avoid heavy irrigation and high Nitrogen during flowering, as moisture and soft growth encourage this disease to take hold.

Look for spindle or "eye-shaped" spots with grey centers on the leaves. To treat, spray Tricyclazole (0.6g/liter) or Carbendazim (1g/liter). Avoid giving all your Urea fertilizer at once; splitting the dose keeps the leaves from becoming too soft and "juicy" for the fungus. Always treat seeds with Pseudomonas fluorescens before sowing to build early leaf strength.

This shows as yellow-to-white wavy streaks starting from the leaf tips. Since chemicals can't "cure" bacteria easily, spray a mix of Streptocycline (1g in 10L) and Copper Oxychloride (20g) to stop the spread. Reduce Nitrogen fertilizer immediately and drain the field water for 3 days. This stops the bacteria from swimming from one plant to the next through the water.

You will see small, dark brown oval spots that look like sesame seeds on the leaves. This usually happens in "hungry" or weak soil. To treat, spray Mancozeb (2g/liter). Long-term, you must improve soil health by adding Zinc and Potash. It is often called the "poor farmer’s disease" because it only attacks plants that aren't getting enough nutrition from the ground.

Large, greenish-grey "snake-skin" patches appear on the leaf sheaths and spread up to the leaf blades. Spray Hexaconazole (2ml/liter) or Validamycin (2ml/liter) directly at the base and on the affected leaves. Avoid planting too closely; wider spacing allows the wind to dry the leaves. Keep the field bunds clean of grass and weeds where the fungus hides.

This is a nutrition problem where the young leaves turn yellow at the base and develop rusty brown spots. To fix it, spray a mixture of Zinc Sulphate (5g) and Lime (2.5g) per 1 liter of water. You will see the leaves turn green again in 7–10 days. For the next crop, make sure to apply 25kg of Zinc Sulphate per hectare directly into the soil.

Look for very thin, straight, transparent lines between the leaf veins that eventually turn brown. Spray Streptocycline (1g in 10L) mixed with Copper Oxychloride (30g). Just like Leaf Blight, this disease loves high Nitrogen. Ensure your field has good drainage and avoid walking through the crop when the leaves are wet, as the bacteria can stick to your clothes.

This shows as very short, narrow brown lines that look like pencil marks on the leaves. To treat it, spray Propiconazole (1ml/liter). This disease is a signal that your plant needs more Potassium. Applying Muriate of Potash (MOP) during the early growth stages thickens the leaf walls, making it much harder for the fungus to poke through and start an infection.

The tips of the leaves look bleached or "burnt" with wavy, water-soaked brown bands. Spray Carbendazim (1g/liter) at the first sign of these marks. Avoid heavy Nitrogen doses during the rainy season. This fungus spreads when wet leaves rub against each other, so proper spacing and removing weeds that keep the field too humid are the best ways to prevent it.

The leaves turn a distinct orange-yellow color from the tip downwards, and the plant stops growing. You cannot treat the virus itself, so you must kill the Green Leafhoppers that carry it. Spray Imidacloprid (0.5ml/liter) immediately. If you see only a few yellow plants, pull them out and bury them deep in the mud so the insects don't spread the virus further.

You will see bright red or orange-brown stripes running along the length of the leaf. This usually happens after heavy rains or high winds. To treat, spray Copper Oxychloride (2.5g/liter). Since this is a bacterial infection, avoid using too much Urea, which makes the stripes grow faster. Ensure the field is not overcrowded so the leaves can dry out quickly after it rains.

Small, slightly raised black spots appear on both sides of the leaf, looking like tiny specks of charcoal. It usually doesn't kill the plant but reduces the leaf's ability to make food. Spraying Mancozeb (2g/liter) or Copper Oxychloride (3g/liter) can control it. It is most common in shaded areas of the field, so ensure your crop gets plenty of direct sunlight.

You will see small, circular spots with light grey centers and dark red-brown borders. To treat, spray Mancozeb (2g/liter) or Carbendazim (1g/liter). If the leaves start falling off, ensure you remove and burn them. Avoid overhead watering, as splashing water spreads the fungal spores to healthy leaves.

This appears as a white, flour-like powder on the underside of leaves, while the top shows yellow patches. In dry, warm weather, it spreads fast. Spray wettable Sulfur (3g/liter) or Dinocap (1ml/liter). A home remedy is a mixture of baking soda and water (5g/liter). Ensure good spacing for better airflow between plants.

Look for small, water-soaked dark spots that eventually turn brown and "warty." Spray Streptocycline (1g in 10L) mixed with Copper Oxychloride (2g/liter). Use disease-free seeds and avoid working in the field when plants are wet. Rotate crops so you aren't planting peppers or tomatoes in the same spot every year.

The leaves curl upwards, become small, and look "crinkled" or leathery. This is spread by tiny whiteflies. You cannot "cure" the virus, so focus on the insects. Spray Neem oil (5ml/liter) or Imidacloprid (0.5ml/liter). Install yellow sticky traps (15 per acre) to catch whiteflies. Pull out and bury infected plants immediately.

This causes large, dark-brown water-soaked patches on the leaves and leads to sudden wilting. It usually strikes during heavy rains. To treat, spray Metalaxyl + Mancozeb (2g/liter). Improve your field's drainage immediately so water doesn't stand. Use raised beds for planting to keep the "collar" of the plant dry and safe from soil fungus.

The leaves show a "mosaic" pattern of light and dark green patches. This is spread by aphids or through touch. Control aphids using sticky traps and Neem spray. Always wash your hands and tools with soap after touching a sick plant. There is no chemical cure; infected plants must be removed and destroyed to save the rest.

It starts as small black spots on leaves and causes the branch tips to dry up like they are dying back. Spray Copper Oxychloride (3g/liter) or Azoxystrobin (1ml/liter). Use healthy seeds and treat them with Trichoderma before sowing. Keep the field clean and ensure you aren't over-fertilizing with Nitrogen.

Small, circular spots with white centers and tiny black dots (spores) inside them. This can cause the plant to lose all its leaves. Spraying Chlorothalonil (2g/liter) or Mancozeb (2.5g/liter) works very well. Remove the infected lower leaves by hand and improve air circulation by pruning extra branches near the bottom of the plant.

A fuzzy grey mold grows on leaves, stems, or flowers during cool, damp weather. It enters through wounds. The best treatment is airflow—prune your plants and keep them spaced out. If it spreads, spray Carbendazim (1g/liter). Avoid high humidity by using drip irrigation instead of overhead sprinklers.

Young leaves turn bronze and develop small, dark spots or rings. Spread by tiny insects called Thrips. Control Thrips using blue sticky traps and by spraying Fipronil or Spinosad. Keep the field borders free of weeds where thrips hide. Once a plant is infected, it cannot be cured and should be removed.

Leaves wilt quickly as a white, "cottony" mold grows on the stem at the soil line. It looks like small mustard seeds are stuck to the stem. Deep plow the field in summer to bury the fungus. Solarise the soil with plastic sheets. Drench the base of the plants with a Trichoderma solution to protect the roots and stem.

The lower leaves turn yellow and the plant wilts, often on just one side first. Since this is in the soil, sprays don't help much. Drench the soil with Carbendazim (2g/liter). Mixing Trichoderma into your compost before planting is the best organic prevention. Ensure your soil isn't constantly soggy, as the fungus loves wet roots.

Also called Botrytis. You will see grey, fuzzy mold on berries, usually after rain. Improve airflow by spacing plants well and weeding. Pick and bury rotting fruit immediately so spores don't spread. Avoid overhead watering. If rain is heavy during flowering, spray Cyprodinil + Fludioxonil (Switch), but keeping plants dry and mulched is the most effective cure.

Leaves curl upward like a cup and show white powdery dust underneath. This happens in humid conditions. Spray wettable Sulfur (2g/liter) or a baking soda solution (5g/liter) to change the leaf surface pH. If growing in a polyhouse, open vents to lower humidity. Ensure sunlight reaches the inner leaves to keep the plant dry.

Black, sunken spots appear on fruit; it can also kill runners. It spreads via infected nursery plants or splashing rain. Use disease-free seedlings. Use drip irrigation to stop water splashing soil spores onto fruit. Mulch with straw/plastic to create a barrier between fruit and soil. Spray Copper Oxychloride or Mancozeb if spots appear on runners.

Small purple spots with white/grey centers on leaves. It attacks older leaves first. Remove and burn these infected leaves to lower the disease load. Spray Copper-based fungicides (2g/liter) or Mancozeb. Do not work in the field when plants are wet, as your clothes can carry the fungus from sick to healthy plants.

Irregular purple or brown spots without white centers. Eventually, the leaves look "scorched" or burnt and dry up. It spreads by splashing water. The treatment is similar to Leaf Spot: remove old debris and apply fungicides like Captan or Thiram. keeping the plant vigorous with good nutrition helps it resist this infection better than weak plants.

Large, V-shaped brown spots start from the leaf edge and move inward. It often happens after harvest. Sanitate the field by removing old leaves. If the infection is severe, spray with Carbendazim or Thiophanate-methyl. Since this fungus survives on dead leaves in winter, cleaning your field at the end of the season is the best prevention.

The plant looks stunted and wilts even with water. If you cut the root, the core is rusty red (not white). It thrives in waterlogged soil. There is no cure; remove infected plants. Prevention is key: plant on raised beds (15cm high) for drainage. Dip new roots in Metalaxyl solution before planting.

The entire plant collapses suddenly. Cutting the crown (the thick stem base) reveals reddish-brown rot inside. Avoid over-watering and heavy soils. Use Fosetyl-Aluminium (Aliette) as a drench if permitted in your area. Use certified disease-free transplants, as this often comes from the nursery. Do not plant strawberries in low spots where water collects.

Fruit becomes hard, brown, leathery, and tastes bitter. This happens when fruit touches wet soil or mud splashes on it. The best fix is a physical barrier: use a thick layer of straw mulch or plastic so berries never touch dirt. Harvest ripe fruit quickly. If heavy rains are forecast, protect with a Captan spray beforehand.

Older outer leaves turn brown and dry while inner leaves stay green. The fungus stays in soil for years. Do not plant strawberries where you recently grew tomatoes, potatoes, or brinjal. If soil is infected, use Soil Solarisation (covering wet soil with clear plastic in hot summer) to cook the fungus. There is no chemical cure for infected plants.

Plants wilt rapidly, and roots turn dark brown/black. It loves warm weather (above 25°C). Since this is a soil-borne fungus, chemical sprays on leaves won't help. Drench soil with Trichoderma viride bio-fungicide regularly to protect roots. Solarise the soil before planting. If a plant dies, remove it with a shovel of soil surrounding it to remove the fungus.

This is not one disease but a mix of fungi, nematodes, and poor soil health. Roots turn black and rot. It happens in compacted, old soil. Improve soil aeration by adding organic matter (compost). Rotate crops every 2-3 years. Do not replant strawberries in the same spot immediately. Use bio-agents like Trichoderma and Pseudomonas to boost root health.

Small, water-soaked spots on the underside of leaves that look translucent when held up to light. Later they turn brown. Since this is bacterial, fungicides don't work well. Avoid overhead sprinklers completely. Spray Copper Hydroxide to limit spread. Do not harvest or prune when plants are wet.

Plants wilt during the day and recover at night, eventually dying. A milky ooze comes out if you cut the stem and put it in water. There is no cure. Remove and burn infected plants. Control weeds strictly. Rotate with mustard or marigold crops to suppress soil bacteria naturally. Ensure your tools are sterilized with bleach between rows.

Plants look stunted, and leaves may have uneven yellow patches, but symptoms are often unclear. It is spread by aphids. You cannot cure a virus. Control aphids using sticky traps and Neem oil sprays. Always buy "certified virus-free" plants from a lab or nursery. Remove any plant that looks dwarf or sickly immediately.

Leaves look crinkled, distorted, or have yellow spots. Also spread by aphids. The management is the same as other viruses: strict insect control. Keep the field border clean of weeds where aphids hide. If you see one infected plant, assume nearby plants might have it too and monitor them closely.

The flower petals turn into small green leaves, and the fruit looks woody. This is caused by phytoplasma spread by Leafhoppers. It looks strange but is serious. Pull out infected plants immediately. Control leafhoppers with appropriate insecticides (like Imidacloprid) or sticky traps. Keep the area free of weeds which host the hoppers.

Plants are weak/stunted. Roots have swollen "knots" or galls. Plant African Marigold flowers thickly between rows or as a rotation crop; their roots release chemicals that repel nematodes. Apply Neem Cake (200kg/acre) to the soil before planting. Use bio-nematicides like Paecilomyces lilacinus mixed with manure.

A white, grey, or yellow slimy coating appears on leaves or stems. It looks scary but actually doesn't hurt the plant much; it just sits on top. It usually goes away when the weather dries. You can wash it off with a strong jet of water. No chemical treatment is usually needed. Improve airflow to prevent it.

Berries develop pale, bleached patches where the hot sun hits them. This isn't a disease but heat damage. Ensure the plant has good leaf cover to shade the berries. In extreme heat, use shade nets (30% shade). Water frequently to keep the plants cool during peak afternoon heat.

Fruit looks puffed and stays white/pink instead of turning red, and tastes bland. This happens due to too much Nitrogen fertilizer or cloudy weather during ripening. Reduce Urea/Nitrogen application during fruiting. Supplement with Potassium and Calcium to improve fruit color and firmness.

Fruit is deformed, twisted, or has a "nub" end. This is caused by poor pollination (lack of bees) or frost damage during flowering. Avoid using strong pesticides during bloom so you don't kill bees. If frost is expected, cover plants with row covers. Boron deficiency can also cause this, so a foliar Boron spray may help.

Avoid overhead watering. If rain is heavy during flowering, spray Cyprodinil + Fludioxonil (Switch), but keeping plants dry and mulched is the most effective cure.
