If frost is expected, cover plants with row covers. Boron deficiency can also cause this, so a foliar Boron spray may help.

Often called the "Cancer of Sugarcane." The plant dries up, and if you split the cane open, the inside is red with white cross-patches and smells like alcohol. Prevention is the only cure. Use resistant varieties (like Co 86032). Never plant seeds from a field that had Red Rot. Dip seed setts in Carbendazim (1g/liter) before planting. Rotate crops with rice or mustard for one season to break the cycle.

A long, black, dusty "whip" grows from the top of the plant. It looks like a burnt stick. Do not just cut it off! Gently cover the whip with a plastic bag before cutting it so the black dust (spores) doesn't fly onto other plants. Burn the bag. Remove the entire clump (roots and all). Treat seed setts with Propiconazole (1ml/liter) before sowing. Avoid keeping a "Ratoon" (second crop) if you had Smut.

The cane dries up and shrinks. If you cut it open, the center is hollow and light violet/brown. It usually happens when the plant is close to harvest. Avoid waterlogging; ensure your field drains well. Stop irrigation for a few weeks if you see wilting to reduce spread. Do not use seed from wilted fields. Apply Trichoderma viride (bio-fungicide) mixed with manure in the soil.

The top leaves get twisted, wrinkled, and shortened. White or yellow patches appear at the base of leaves. It often happens in the rainy season. It usually recovers on its own, but if severe, spray Copper Oxychloride (3g/liter) or Carbendazim (1g/liter). Adding micronutrients (Magnesium and Zinc) helps the plant recover faster.

The plant produces many thin, small, white/yellow shoots at the base, looking like grass instead of cane. It will not produce any sugar. This is spread by aphids. Heat Treatment is the best cure: treat seed setts with hot water (50°C) for 2 hours before planting. Dig out and burn infected clumps immediately. Do not take a ratoon crop from an infected field.

The midrib (center vein) of the upper leaves turns bright yellow, while the rest of the leaf stays green. Cane growth slows down. It is spread by aphids. Use Tissue Culture seedlings (virus-free) for planting. Spray Imidacloprid (0.5ml/liter) to kill the aphids that spread it. Give the crop good fertilizer and water so it can tolerate the virus and still yield well.

This attacks the seed setts after planting. The inside of the sett turns black and smells like ripe pineapple. The buds fail to sprout. This happens if the cut ends of the seed are not treated. Always dip the cut ends of your seed setts in a solution of Carbendazim or Propiconazole for 15 minutes before planting to seal the wound.

White "pencil lines" run along the leaf veins. Later, the leaf dries up and looks scalded (burned by hot water). The cane may sprout side shoots. Use certified disease-free seeds. Sterilize your harvesting knives with bleach or by heating them, as the bacteria spreads through tools. Remove infected plants immediately.

Long, narrow red stripes appear on the leaves. If it moves to the top shoot, the top may rot (Top Rot) and smell bad. Since it is bacterial, fungicides won't work perfectly. Improve field drainage and avoid overhead sprinklers. You can spray Copper Oxychloride to limit the spread.

Small, elongated orange or brown spots appear on the leaves. If you touch them, orange powder comes off on your finger. It happens in cool, humid weather. Usually, the sun kills it as the weather warms up. If severe, spray Mancozeb (2g/liter) or Propiconazole (1ml/liter). Remove weeds that block sunlight from reaching the lower leaves.

Leaves show a pattern of dark and light green patches (mottling). The cane stalks may split. It is spread by aphids and infected knives. There is no chemical cure. Use resistant varieties. The most important step is roguing: check your field frequently and pull out any young plants showing these symptoms early in the season.

You won't see clear symptoms on leaves, but the plant simply doesn't grow tall. The yield drops significantly in the ratoon (second) crop. The inside of the nodes may have orange/red dots. The only prevention is Hot Water Treatment of seeds (50°C for 2 hours) and sterilizing cutting knives with Lysol or bleach between fields.

New leaves turn completely white or pale yellow/cream, but the veins might stay green. This is not a disease but a lack of Iron in the soil (common in calcareous/chalky soils). Spray Ferrous Sulphate (5g/liter) mixed with Citric Acid (1g/liter) on the leaves 2-3 times at 10-day intervals.

The most dangerous disease. Look for spindle-shaped spots with grey centers on leaves. Spray Tricyclazole (0.6g/liter) or Carbendazim (1g/liter). If the "neck" or "earhead" turns black, spray immediately to save grains. Avoid over-using Urea; split your nitrogen doses. Use resistant seeds like GPU-28 or ML-365.

Small, oval, light-brown spots appear and can cover the whole leaf. Spray Mancozeb (2g/liter) as soon as spots appear. This fungus hides on seeds, so treat them with Thiram or Captan (3g/kg) before sowing. Rotating the crop with legumes (like pulses) helps clean the soil naturally.

Shows as long, narrow brown spots. Heavy infection makes leaves look "burnt." Spray Mancozeb (2g/liter) or Copper Oxychloride (3g/liter). Ensure proper spacing between plants so sunlight can hit the lower leaves; sunlight is a natural killer for these fungal spores. Maintain soil fertility with organic manure.

Leaves turn pale yellow and look "shredded" or twisted. The grain head turns into a bunch of green leaves instead of seeds. There is no cure once it reaches the earhead. Pull out and burn infected plants immediately. Prevent it by treating seeds with Metalaxyl (4g/kg) and ensuring the field is well-drained.

Young seedlings turn brown and die shortly after emerging. This is a soil-borne fungus. Drench the nursery area with Copper Oxychloride (2g/liter). To prevent it, always use raised beds for your nursery so water doesn't stand. Treat seeds with Trichoderma (10g/kg) to provide a biological shield against soil rot.

Large, irregular "bleached" patches appear on the leaves, looking like bands. It spreads fast in very humid weather. Spray Hexaconazole (2ml/liter) or Propiconazole (1ml/liter). Keep the field free of weeds and avoid planting too densely. This fungus loves high humidity, so keeping the area airy is your best defense.

Leaves show pale green or yellow streaks and a patchy appearance. The plant stays small and stunted. Spread by Aphids. You cannot cure the virus; you must kill the insects. Spray Neem oil (5ml/liter) or Dimethoate (1.7ml/liter). Pull out infected plants immediately to prevent the aphids from carrying the virus to healthy neighbors.

Fine, transparent, water-soaked streaks along the leaf veins that eventually turn brown. Spray Streptocycline (1g in 10L) mixed with Copper Oxychloride (20g). Avoid working in the field when plants are wet. Adding Potash (Potassium) to your fertilizer schedule helps the leaf develop a tougher skin against these bacteria.

While it affects grains, the first sign is often the darkening of the earhead tissues. Grains turn into green or black powdery sacs. Since it is seed-borne, seed treatment with Carbendazim (2g/kg) is the only effective way to stop it. If you see smutted heads, remove them carefully in a plastic bag and burn them.

Lower leaves turn yellow and the whole plant wilts and dries up. Drench the base of the plants with Carbendazim (2g/liter). The best prevention is to mix Trichoderma viride (2kg/acre) with compost and apply it to the soil before sowing. This beneficial fungus eats the disease-causing fungus in the ground.

The leaves curl upward, become small, and look leathery. This is spread by Whiteflies. There is no chemical cure for the virus. Control the insects: install yellow sticky traps (15 per acre) and spray Neem oil (5ml/liter) or Imidacloprid (0.5ml/liter). Pull out and bury infected plants immediately to save the rest of your field.

The leaves curl downward, looking like an inverted boat. The leaf veins turn silver or bronzed. This is caused by sap-sucking thrips. Spray Fipronil (2ml/liter) or Spinosad (0.5ml/liter). Use blue sticky traps. Keeping the field moist helps, as thrips thrive in dry, dusty weather.

Tips of branches turn black and dry from the top downwards. It also causes small black dots on leaves. Spray Copper Oxychloride (3g/liter) or Azoxystrobin (1ml/liter). Prune and burn the dead branch tips. Always treat seeds with Trichoderma before sowing to prevent this fungus from starting in the nursery.

White, flour-like dust appears on the underside of leaves, while the top shows yellow patches. This happens in warm, dry weather. Spray wettable Sulfur (3g/liter) or Hexaconazole (2ml/liter). A simple home remedy is spraying a mixture of baking soda (5g/liter) and water. Ensure plants have enough space for air to flow.

Small, circular "frog-eye" spots with white centers and brown borders appear. If not treated, leaves turn yellow and fall off. Spray Mancozeb (2g/liter) or Carbendazim (1g/liter). Avoid high-density planting and remove fallen leaves from the field, as they harbor the fungal spores.

Small, dark, greasy-looking spots appear on leaves. This causes heavy leaf drop during rainy seasons. Spray Streptocycline (1g in 10L) mixed with Copper Oxychloride (20g). Avoid overhead watering; use drip or furrow irrigation. Do not enter the field when the plants are wet to avoid spreading the bacteria.

Also called "Wet Rot," young leaves and flower buds turn black and rot. They look like they are covered in tiny black pins. This happens in very humid weather. Spray Copper Oxychloride (3g/liter). Improve field drainage and avoid over-using Nitrogen fertilizer, which makes the plant tissue too soft for the fungus.

Leaves show a patchy "mosaic" of light and dark green. This is spread by Aphids. There is no cure; focus on killing the aphids using yellow sticky traps and spraying Thiamethoxam (0.3g/liter). Pull out and destroy infected plants. Always wash your hands with soap after touching a sick plant before touching healthy ones.

Large, dark-brown water-soaked spots appear on leaves and the stem base rots. This happens during the monsoon. Spray Metalaxyl + Mancozeb (2g/liter) and improve drainage immediately. Planting on raised beds is the best way to keep the plant's "collar" area dry and safe from this fungus.

Distinctive sunken black spots appear on leaves, which eventually turn into "holes." This is the same fungus that rots the fruit. Spray Propiconazole (1ml/liter) or Mancozeb (2.5g/liter). Ensure the field is clean of old plant debris. Mulching the soil with plastic or straw helps prevent soil-borne spores from splashing onto the lower leaves during rain.

A fuzzy grey mold grows on leaves and flowers during cool, damp weather. It usually starts on wounded leaves. The best treatment is ventilation—prune extra leaves to let air move through. If severe, spray Carbendazim (1g/liter). Avoid using overhead sprinklers that keep the leaves wet for long periods.

Lower leaves turn yellow and the whole plant wilts suddenly. Since this is a soil-borne fungus, drench the base of the plant with Carbendazim (2g/liter). The best prevention is to mix Trichoderma (2kg/acre) into your farmyard manure before planting. Ensure the field is not waterlogged, as the fungus loves wet, heavy soil.

A white, "cotton-like" mold grows on the stem near the soil, and the leaves wilt rapidly. You may see small, mustard-seed-like structures on the mold. Drench the soil with a solution of Trichoderma. Deep summer plowing and soil solarization (covering soil with plastic in May) are very effective in killing this soil fungus before the next crop.

Orange or rust-colored velvety spots appear on the leaves. This is common in very humid, tropical areas. Spray Copper Oxychloride (3g/liter). This usually happens when the plant is weak; ensuring proper fertilization (NPK) and good drainage will help the plant recover. It is more common in shaded parts of the field.

You will see yellow "V-shaped" patches on leaf edges. Spray Streptocycline (1g in 10L) mixed with Copper Oxychloride (20g). Always use "hot water treated" seeds (50°C for 30 mins) to kill hidden bacteria. Avoid working in the field when plants are wet. This is the most serious cabbage disease in India; rotating crops for 2 years is essential.

Dark-brown circular spots with "target rings" appear on leaves. Spray Mancozeb (2g/liter) or Chlorothalonil (2g/liter). This fungus loves wet weather. Ensure good drainage and remove old, infected leaves. Rotating your cabbage with non-mustard family crops (like onions) for 2 years helps clean the soil and prevents the disease from returning next season.

Yellow patches appear on top of leaves with white, "cottony" growth underneath. Spray Metalaxyl + Mancozeb (2g/liter). Avoid overhead watering that keeps leaves wet overnight. Thin out plants so air moves freely between the heads. This keeps leaves dry and stops the fungus. Start sprays early in the nursery stage if symptoms appear.

Leaves wilt during the day but "recover" at night. If you pull the plant, roots look swollen like "clubs." There is no chemical cure once it starts. The best treatment is to increase soil pH by adding Lime (Chuna) to the soil during land prep. Avoid planting cabbage or cauliflower in the same spot for at least 3 years to starve the soil fungus.

This causes a mushy, water-soaked rot on the head that smells very foul. It spreads fast in warm, wet weather through wounds. To treat, spray Copper Oxychloride (3g/liter) or Streptocycline. Harvest only in dry weather and handle heads carefully to avoid scratches. Clear all plant debris after harvest. Rotating with corn or legumes helps reduce the bacteria in the soil.

White, flour-like powder appears on leaf surfaces, eventually covering them. Spray wettable Sulfur (3g/liter) or Dinocap (1ml/liter). This usually happens in dry, warm weather. A simple home remedy is a mixture of baking soda and water (5g/liter). Avoid using too much Nitrogen fertilizer, as it causes soft, "juicy" growth that the fungus finds very easy to infect.

Shiny, white, "blister-like" spots appear on the underside of leaves. Spray Copper Oxychloride (3g/liter) or Mancozeb (2g/liter). This usually appears during the winter months. Keep the field free of "Mustard" weeds, as the disease jumps from wild mustard to your cabbage. Ensure balanced fertilization and avoid heavy irrigation during cool mornings to keep leaves dry.

Circular, light-brown spots with tiny black dots appear on leaves. The stem near the ground turns black and rots. Spray Carbendazim (1g/liter). Use healthy seeds and treat them with hot water before planting. Remove all "cabbage trash" after harvest, as the fungus survives in the stems. Deep summer plowing kills the spores hiding in the soil.

Leaves show a patchy "mosaic" of light and dark green and may look wrinkled. Spread by Aphids. You cannot cure the virus; you must kill the aphids using yellow sticky traps and spraying Neem oil (5ml/liter). Pull out and bury infected plants immediately to prevent the insects from carrying the virus to healthy ones. Do not save seeds from infected plants.

The edges of the inner leaves turn brown and dry. This is caused by a Calcium deficiency, often due to uneven watering. To fix, maintain steady soil moisture (don't let it get bone dry) and spray Calcium Nitrate (2-3g/liter) directly on the plant every 15 days. Avoid over-fertilizing with Potash or Nitrogen, as they can block the plant from drinking Calcium.

The cabbage head suddenly cracks open. This happens when heavy rain follows a dry spell; the plant drinks too much water too fast. Maintain uniform soil moisture with regular, small waterings. If a heavy rain is coming and your cabbage is already large, harvest it immediately before the rain starts. Mulching helps keep the soil moisture levels stable.

The base of the stem on young plants turns dark, hard, and thin like a wire. This is caused by soil fungi (Rhizoctonia). Drench the soil with Copper Oxychloride (2g/liter). To prevent it, always use raised nursery beds to ensure good drainage. Mixing Trichoderma into your compost before planting provides a natural shield that protects the delicate stems from soil attack.

This is the most serious Indian brinjal disease. Leaves become tiny, crowded, and bushy; the plant stops fruiting. It is spread by leafhoppers. There is no cure for an infected plant—pull it out and bury it immediately. To prevent it, spray Dimethoate (2ml/liter) or Neem oil to kill the insects. Growing a border of maize or bajra helps block the leafhoppers.

You will see circular brown spots on leaves and soft, sunken rotted spots on fruits. To treat, spray Mancozeb (2g/liter) or Carbendazim (1g/liter). Always treat seeds with Thiram (3g/kg) before sowing. Remove and burn any infected fruits or leaves immediately to stop the fungal spores from flying to healthy plants.

The plant suddenly droops and dies while still green. There is no chemical cure. Use resistant varieties like Arka Neelkanth. Before planting, dip seedling roots in a Pseudomonas fluorescens solution. Rotate your crop with grains like ragi or maize; never plant brinjal where you just grew tomatoes, chillies, or potatoes.

Small, circular yellow-brown spots appear on leaves. Spray Copper Oxychloride (3g/liter) or Mancozeb (2g/liter). This fungus loves high humidity and crowded plants. Ensure proper spacing so sunlight hits the lower leaves. Removing older, infected leaves from the bottom of the plant helps reduce the "fungal load" in your field.

Look for dark-brown spots with "concentric rings" (like a target). Spray Chlorothalonil (2g/liter) or Mancozeb (2.5g/liter). Since the fungus survives on old plant debris, always clean your field after harvest. Deep summer plowing is very helpful in killing the spores hiding in the ground during the hot months.

This kills young seedlings in the nursery by rotting the stem at soil level. Treat seeds with Trichoderma viride (4g/kg) before sowing. Always use raised nursery beds for better drainage. If you see rot, drench the soil with Copper Oxychloride (2g/liter). Keep the soil moist but never soggy.

White, flour-like patches appear on the underside of leaves, with yellow spots on top. Spray wettable Sulfur (3g/liter) or Hexaconazole (2ml/liter). A simple home remedy is a mixture of baking soda and water (5g/liter). Avoid over-using Nitrogen, as it makes the leaves soft and easy for the fungus to infect.

Leaves show a patchy "mosaic" of light and dark green and look deformed. Spread by Aphids. You cannot cure the virus; you must kill the aphids. Install yellow sticky traps (15 per acre) and spray Neem oil (5ml/liter) or Imidacloprid (0.5ml/liter). Pull out and bury infected plants immediately.

Lower leaves turn yellow and the plant wilts slowly. The stem inside turns brown. Drench the soil with Carbendazim (2g/liter). The best prevention is to mix Trichoderma into your manure before planting. This beneficial fungus eats the disease fungus in the soil. Avoid waterlogging, as wet soil helps the fungus move.

The plant looks yellow and stunted; roots have small, round "knots" or swellings. Plant African Marigold flowers between brinjal rows—their roots release chemicals that kill these worms. Apply Neem Cake (250kg/acre) to the soil. Use Paecilomyces lilacinus (bio-agent) in the soil during land preparation.

A white, "silky" mold grows on the stem just above the soil line, and the plant wilts. You may see small, brown, mustard-seed-like structures (sclerotia). Drench the base of the plant with Copper Oxychloride (3g/liter). Deep summer plowing and soil solarization (covering with plastic) are very effective in killing the fungus in the soil.

Caused by Phyllosticta, this causes bleach-colored spots on leaves and rots the fruit near the stem. Spray Mancozeb (2g/liter). Avoid high humidity and ensure the plants are not overcrowded. This disease is most common during the monsoon season. Use drip irrigation to keep the fruit and leaves dry.

The plant stays very short with small leaves and yellowing. It is often confused with Little Leaf but is spread by a different insect. Pull out and destroy infected plants immediately. Control the spreading insects (Leafhoppers and Aphids) using Neem-based sprays. Avoid planting near old, infected brinjal fields.

While not a "disease," cracks on the fruit allow fungi to enter. This is caused by sudden heavy rain after a dry period or Boron deficiency. Maintain uniform soil moisture. Spray Borax (2g/liter) once during the flowering stage to keep the fruit skin flexible and strong.

You will see yellow, angular patches on top of leaves and purplish-grey "fuzz" underneath. Spray Metalaxyl + Mancozeb (2g/liter) immediately. Avoid overhead watering. Growing vines on a trellis (Mandap) is the best way to keep leaves dry and stop the fungus from spreading.

White, flour-like powder appears on both sides of the leaf. Spray wettable Sulfur (3g/liter) or Carbendazim (1g/liter). A simple home remedy is a mixture of baking soda and water (5g/liter). Avoid over-using Nitrogen, which makes leaves soft and easy to infect. Keeping the field weed-free reduces spores.

Leaves show light and dark green patches and become wrinkled. Spread by Aphids. There is no chemical cure. Control the insects: use yellow sticky traps (15 per acre) and spray Neem oil (5ml/liter) or Imidacloprid (0.5ml/liter). Pull out and bury infected plants immediately to save the rest of the field.

The vine yellows and wilts suddenly, usually during the hot part of the day. This is soil-borne. Drench the soil with Carbendazim (2g/liter). The best prevention is to mix Trichoderma viride (2kg/acre) with manure before planting. Use certified seeds and ensure the field has excellent drainage.

Fruit turns soft and watery where it touches wet soil, often with a white mold. Spray Mancozeb (3g/liter) or Copper Oxychloride (2g/liter). Staking the vines is the best way to keep fruit off the ground. Remove and destroy rotted fruits immediately. Using plastic mulch prevents soil spores from splashing.

Small, water-soaked spots that look "square" because they are blocked by leaf veins. Spray Streptocycline (1g in 10L) mixed with Copper Oxychloride (20g). This bacteria spreads through splashing water. Avoid working in the field when leaves are wet. Use drip irrigation instead of sprinklers.

Small circular spots with grey centers and brown borders. Spray Mancozeb (2g/liter) or Chlorothalonil (2g/liter). This fungus loves hot, humid weather. Prune lower leaves near the soil to improve air movement. Clean up and burn old plant debris after harvest to kill hidden spores.

Water-soaked yellowish spots on leaves and sunken black spots on fruit. Spray Carbendazim (1g/liter) or Propiconazole (1ml/liter). Treat seeds with Thiram (3g/kg) before sowing. Avoid evening irrigation; morning watering allows the sun to dry the leaves quickly, preventing infection.

The vine grows hundreds of tiny, crowded leaves that look like a broom. Spread by leafhoppers. Once infected, it cannot be cured. Pull out and bury the vine immediately. Control leafhoppers with yellow sticky traps and sprays of Dimethoate (2ml/liter) or Neem Oil.

The veins of the leaf turn bright yellow while the rest stays green. This is spread by Whiteflies. Control the whiteflies with yellow sticky traps and sprays of Acetamiprid (0.4g/liter). Pull out infected plants immediately. Keep the field free of weeds like Malvastrum, which act as a home for the virus.

Small, water-soaked spots on leaves that turn into "shot holes." Fruit develops oozing brown spots. Spray Chlorothalonil (2g/liter) or Mancozeb (2g/liter). This disease loves cool, moist nights. Avoid planting too early in the winter. Use disease-free seeds and rotate crops with non-cucurbits for 2 years.

Small brown spots with "target-like" rings appear on leaves. Spray Mancozeb (2.5g/liter) or Iprodione. This usually attacks older leaves first. Ensure the plant has enough nutrition (especially Potash) to stay strong. Remove old leaves from the base to stop the fungus from climbing up the vine.

Plants look stunted and yellow; roots have round knots or swellings. Plant African Marigold flowers between bitter gourd rows. Apply Neem Cake (250kg/acre) to the soil during land preparation. Use the bio-agent Purpureocillium lilacinum in the soil to naturally kill the worm eggs.

Kills young seedlings by rotting the stem at the soil line. Treat seeds with Trichoderma (10g/kg) or Thiram (3g/kg). Use raised nursery beds and do not over-water. If you see rot, drench the soil with Copper Oxychloride (2g/liter). Ensure the nursery is in a sunny, well-ventilated spot.

The most common issue. Look for circular spots with grey centers and reddish-purple borders. Spray Mancozeb (2g/liter) or Carbendazim (1g/liter). This fungus loves humidity. Space plants properly to ensure leaves dry quickly. Remove and burn heavily infected leaves immediately to stop the spread.

Dark brown to black spots with "target-like" rings appear on leaves. Spray Chlorothalonil (2g/liter) or Copper Oxychloride (3g/liter). It usually attacks older leaves first. Ensure the soil has enough Potassium (Potash) to keep leaves strong. Clean up plant debris after harvest to kill hidden spores.

Pale yellow patches on top of leaves with grey-purple "fuzz" underneath. Spray Metalaxyl + Mancozeb (2g/liter). This disease loves cool, wet weather. Avoid overhead watering in the evening. Rotate beetroot with crops like onions or carrots for 2 years to break the fungus life cycle.

White, flour-like powder appears on both sides of the leaf. Spray wettable Sulfur (3g/liter) or Hexaconazole (2ml/liter). A simple home remedy is a baking soda and water mixture (5g/liter). Avoid over-using Nitrogen, which makes leaves soft and easy to infect.

Patchy "mosaic" of light and dark green on wrinkled leaves. Spread by Aphids. There is no chemical cure. Control the insects: use yellow sticky traps and spray Neem oil (5ml/liter) or Imidacloprid (0.5ml/liter). Pull out and bury infected plants immediately. Keep the field free of weeds.

Small, irregular, water-soaked spots that turn dark brown or black. Spray Streptocycline (1g in 10L) mixed with Copper Oxychloride (2g/liter). Avoid working in the field when leaves are wet. Use drip irrigation to keep foliage dry and ensure excellent field drainage.

Large, light-brown spots with tiny black dots inside. Often a sign of Boron deficiency. Spray Carbendazim (1g/liter) and apply Borax (10kg/acre) to the soil. You can also spray a Boron-based liquid fertilizer (2g/liter) once during the growth stage to strengthen the plant.

Leaves curl upward, become leathery, and veins turn purple. Spread by Beet Leafhoppers. No cure exists; focus on insects. Spray Dimethoate (2ml/liter) and use yellow sticky traps. Remove and destroy infected plants immediately to prevent the whole field from being stunted.

Small, raised, reddish-orange "pustules" (like rust on iron) on leaf undersides. Spray Mancozeb (2g/liter) or Propiconazole (1ml/liter). This usually appears in very humid conditions. Avoid over-irrigating and ensure the field is free of wild weeds that act as host plants.

Very similar to Cercospora but spots are more irregular and have a white, crusty center. Spray Carbendazim (1g/liter) or Mancozeb (2g/liter). This fungus prefers cooler temperatures. Proper crop rotation and removing infected leaf trash after harvest are the best ways to prevent a breakout.

Kills young seedlings in the nursery by rotting the stem at the soil line. Treat seeds with Trichoderma (10g/kg) before sowing. Use raised beds for better drainage. If rot appears, drench soil with Copper Oxychloride (2g/liter). Do not over-water the young seedlings.

Outer leaves turn yellow and wilt, even if the soil is wet. The inner core of the beetroot may show dark streaks. There is no effective chemical spray. Rotate crops with non-host plants like corn or wheat. Solarise the soil in summer by covering it with plastic to kill the fungus.

Older leaves turn thick, brittle, and bright yellow between the veins. Spread by Aphids. There is no cure for the virus. Use yellow sticky traps (15/acre) and spray Thiamethoxam (0.3g/liter) to control the aphids. Keeping the field borders clean of wild weeds is crucial for prevention.

Look for dark brown/black spots with yellow edges on leaf margins. Leaves look "scorched." Spray Mancozeb (2g/liter) or Copper Oxychloride (3g/liter). Avoid overhead watering. Rotate carrots with onions or garlic for 3 years. Use high-quality, treated seeds and ensure the field is well-fertilized to keep plants strong.

Small circular spots with grey centers appear on younger leaves first. Spray Chlorothalonil (2g/liter) or Carbendazim (1g/liter). To prevent this, don't plant too densely; good airflow helps leaves dry. Treat seeds with hot water (50°C for 20 mins) before sowing. Remove crop debris after harvest to stop the fungus from overwintering in the soil.

Yellow, angular spots on leaves that turn dark brown and look "varnished" or shiny underneath. Spray Streptocycline (1g in 10L) mixed with Copper Oxychloride (2g/liter). This spreads through splashing rain. Use drip irrigation to keep leaves dry. Avoid working in the field when plants are wet. Always use disease-free, certified seeds.

White, flour-like powder covers leaves and stems in dry, warm weather. Spray wettable Sulfur (3g/liter) or Hexaconazole (2ml/liter). A home remedy is a baking soda-water mix (5g/liter). Avoid over-using Nitrogen, which creates soft growth that the fungus loves. Ensure the field is weed-free to reduce the count of hidden fungal spores.

Young leaves turn yellow and the center becomes a bushy "rosette." Roots grow many tiny "hairs." Spread by Leafhoppers. There is no cure; pull out and bury infected plants. Control Leafhoppers using yellow sticky traps and sprays of Neem oil (5ml/liter) or Dimethoate (2ml/liter). Keep field borders clear of weeds where insects hide.

A white, cotton-like mold grows on the crown near the soil, rotting the root top. Spray Carbendazim (1g/liter). This loves high humidity. Avoid over-watering and use raised beds for better drainage. Solarise soil in summer by covering it with plastic sheets to kill spores. In storage, keep carrots cool (0°C) and dry.

Seedlings rot at the soil line and fall over shortly after emerging. Treat seeds with Trichoderma viride (4g/kg) or Captan (3g/kg) before sowing. Use raised beds to prevent waterlogging. If rot appears, drench soil with Copper Oxychloride (2g/liter). Allow the soil surface to dry slightly between waterings to discourage fungus.

Plants look yellow and stunted; roots have "knots," galls, or forked shapes. Plant African Marigold between carrot rows—their roots naturally kill these worms. Apply Neem Cake (250kg/acre) during land prep. Use the bio-agent Paecilomyces lilacinus in the soil to protect the growing roots.

Small, sunken grey-to-brown elliptical spots appear across the root. This is caused by excessive soil moisture. Improve field drainage immediately. Avoid over-fertilizing with Nitrogen. Harvest carrots as soon as they are mature, as older carrots are more likely to get infected. Do not plant in heavy clay soils that hold water.

Causes "damping-off" in seedlings and black, sunken lesions on the root crown. Spread through infected seeds. Treat seeds with hot water before sowing. Implement a long crop rotation (3-4 years). Plow crop residue deep into the soil after harvest. Store carrots at very low temperatures (0°C) to stop the rot.

The root turns into a mushy, foul-smelling liquid. Often starts from harvest wounds. Use well-drained soil and avoid wounding plants during harvest. Grade carrots carefully before storage—remove any bruised ones. Rinsing carrots in a very mild bleach solution (1 part bleach to 20 parts water) before storage can help.

Larvae tunnel into roots, leaving "rusty" red-brown tracks that then rot. While a pest, it looks like a disease. Use row covers to prevent flies from laying eggs. Deep plowing in summer kills pupae in the soil. Harvest entire blocks of carrots at once rather than picking randomly to prevent larvae from spreading.

Raised, "corky" or "warty" brown patches appear on the carrot skin. This happens in dry, alkaline soils. Keep the soil consistently moist during the first 6 weeks of growth. If your soil is too alkaline, avoid adding lime. Rotating with crops like rye or wheat can help. Do not use fresh manure right before planting, as it encourages scab.

Occurs mostly in storage as irregular black spots on the skin. The fungus invades through wounds. Harvest carrots gently to avoid scratches. Cool the carrots immediately after harvest to below 5°C. The disease is favored by high humidity and heat during storage, so ensure the storage area has good air circulation and is kept cold.

Leaves turn bright red, orange, or yellow, and the plant is severely stunted. Spread by the willow-carrot aphid. There is no cure for the virus. Control aphids using yellow sticky traps and Neem oil or Dimethoate sprays. Avoid planting near old, overwintered carrot fields which act as a reservoir for the virus and the aphids.

Large, black, water-soaked spots appear on roots, usually during storage. It is caused by the Centrospora fungus. Ensure your field has good drainage. Avoid planting carrots in very cold, wet soils. Rotating with non-host crops and ensuring the carrots are washed and dried properly before cold storage is the most effective way to prevent this rot.

Yellow "V-shaped" patches appear on leaf edges, and veins turn black. This is the most dangerous cauliflower disease. Spray Streptocycline (1g in 10L) mixed with Copper Oxychloride (20g). Always use hot-water treated seeds (50°C for 30 mins). Avoid working in fields when plants are wet to stop the bacteria from spreading.

Yellow patches on top of leaves with white "cottony" growth underneath. Spray Metalaxyl + Mancozeb (2g/liter). This happens in cool, humid weather. Thin out your plants so air can move freely. If it starts in the nursery, spray immediately to prevent taking the disease to the main field.

Dark brown/black circular spots with "target rings" appear on leaves and the curd (head). Spray Mancozeb (2g/liter) or Chlorothalonil (2g/liter). This fungus loves wet weather. Ensure good drainage and remove old infected leaves. Rotating your crop with non-cabbage family plants for 2 years helps clean the soil.

Leaves wilt during the day but "recover" at night. Roots look swollen and deformed like "clubs." There is no chemical cure once it starts. The best treatment is to increase soil pH by adding Lime (Chuna) during land preparation. Avoid planting cauliflower in the same spot for at least 3 years.

The curd turns into a mushy, foul-smelling liquid. It spreads fast in warm, wet weather through wounds. Spray Copper Oxychloride (3g/liter). Harvest only in dry weather and handle heads carefully to avoid scratches. Clear all plant debris after harvest and rotate with corn or legumes to break the cycle.

Leaves become very narrow, twisted, and "thread-like." This is a Molybdenum deficiency, common in acidic soil. To fix, apply Lime to the soil and spray Sodium Molybdate (1g/liter) on the leaves. It is a nutritional problem, so standard fungicides will not work.

The stem becomes hollow and the head turns brownish. This is caused by Boron deficiency. Spray Borax (2g/liter) during the mid-growth stage. Avoid giving too much Nitrogen at once, as rapid growth makes the plant more likely to develop these hollow spaces.

Young seedlings rot at the base and fall over in the nursery. Treat seeds with Trichoderma viride (4g/kg) before sowing. Use raised beds to ensure water drains away. If rot appears, drench the soil with Copper Oxychloride (2g/liter). Allow the soil surface to dry between waterings.

A white, "fluffy" mold grows on the base of the head or stem, turning it watery. Spray Carbendazim (1g/liter). This disease loves high humidity. Avoid over-watering and ensure proper plant spacing for airflow. Solarise your soil in summer with plastic sheets to kill the resting spores before planting.

White, flour-like powder appears on leaf surfaces. Spray wettable Sulfur (3g/liter) or Dinocap (1ml/liter). This happens in dry, warm weather. A simple home remedy is a mixture of baking soda and water (5g/liter). Avoid over-using Nitrogen, which creates soft growth that the fungus finds easy to infect.

Circular, light-brown spots with tiny black dots appear on leaves; the stem near the ground turns black and rots. Spray Carbendazim (1g/liter). Use healthy seeds and treat them with hot water. Remove all old plant debris after harvest. Deep summer plowing is very effective in killing the spores hiding in the soil.

Leaves show a patchy "mosaic" of light and dark green. Spread by Aphids. You cannot cure the virus; you must kill the aphids using yellow sticky traps and spraying Neem oil (5ml/liter). Pull out and bury infected plants immediately to prevent the insects from carrying the virus to healthy neighbors.

The head looks "fuzzy" or loose like a flower. This is caused by high temperatures during the head-forming stage or over-maturity. Choose the right variety for your local climate. Harvest the curd as soon as it reaches its full size while it is still firm and white. Don't let it sit in the field too long.

The plant grows leaves but fails to produce a curd (head). This is often caused by low temperatures or damage to the "growing point" by insects like the Diamondback Moth. Protect young plants from pests early. Use balanced fertilizers; sometimes very low temperatures during the early growth phase can "blind" the plant.

The plant produces a very tiny, useless head ("button"). This happens if the seedlings are too old when transplanted or if they face stress from lack of water or Nitrogen. Always transplant young, healthy seedlings (4-5 weeks old). Ensure the soil has enough Nitrogen and moisture from the very first day of planting.

Twig tips turn brown and dry up, moving down to the leaves. Spray Copper Oxychloride (3g/liter). Prune affected branches 3 inches below the dead part and burn them. This prevents the fungus from reaching the trunk.

Small, circular brown spots appear, leading to yellowing and leaf fall. Spray Mancozeb (2g/liter). Ensure trees are pruned to allow sunlight into the inner branches. Keep the base of the tree weed-free to reduce humidity.

White, flour-like patches on leaves during cool, dry months. Spray wettable Sulfur (3g/liter). A home remedy of Neem oil and baking soda in water works well. Avoid over-watering in winter to keep humidity low.

Affects seedlings in the nursery; the stem at soil level rots and the plant falls. Treat seeds with Trichoderma viride (4g/kg) before sowing. Use raised beds and ensure the nursery gets plenty of sunlight.

Pods develop dark, sunken spots and turn soft. Spray Carbendazim (1g/liter) during flowering. Avoid planting trees too close together and ensure water does not stand at the base, as wet roots invite pod-rotting fungi.

Leaves show patchy green patterns and become deformed. Spread by Aphids. No cure for the virus. Control aphids with yellow sticky traps and Neem oil sprays. Prune affected branches immediately or remove stunted trees to protect the rest.

Leaves turn yellow and the tree wilts suddenly. Common in heavy, wet soils. Drench the root zone with a Trichoderma solution. Plant Moringa on mounds or raised bunds so water drains away from the trunk.

Small orange-to-reddish powdery spots on the underside of leaves. Spray Mancozeb (2.5g/liter) or Propiconazole (1ml/liter). Prune to improve airflow and apply Potash (Potassium) to help leaves resist the rust spores.

A black, "sooty" film covers the leaves. This is actually a fungus growing on the sticky "honeydew" left by insects like Mealybugs or Aphids. To treat, first kill the insects using Neem oil or soap spray. The mold will then dry up and flake off. Washing the leaves with a strong spray of water also helps.

The flower buds turn brown, rot, and fall off before they can become pods. This is common during high humidity. Spray Carbendazim (1g/liter) at the start of the flowering season. Avoid using too much Nitrogen, which makes the flower buds too soft and prone to rot.

Large, woody "knots" or swellings appear on the trunk or roots near the soil line. This is caused by soil bacteria entering through wounds. There is no cure. Avoid wounding the trunk during weeding. If a tree is heavily affected, remove it and do not plant Moringa in that same spot for 3 years.

Dark, sunken areas (cankers) appear on the bark, sometimes oozing gum. The branch above the canker may die. Clean the wound and apply Copper Oxychloride paste. Avoid stress like drought or over-watering, which weakens the tree's "skin" and allows the fungus to enter.

The most destructive okra disease. Leaf veins turn bright yellow while the rest stays green. Spread by Whiteflies. There is no cure for the virus. Control whiteflies using yellow sticky traps (15/acre) and spray Imidacloprid (0.5ml/liter) or Neem oil. Pull out and bury infected plants immediately. Always use resistant varieties like Arka Anamika or Varsha Uphar.

White, flour-like powder appears on both sides of the leaf. This happens in warm, dry weather. Spray wettable Sulfur (3g/liter) or Dinocap (1ml/liter). A home remedy is a mixture of baking soda and water (5g/liter). Avoid overcrowding plants to ensure good airflow, which naturally discourages the fungus.

Small, soot-like black spots on the underside of leaves, while the top shows yellow patches. Leaves eventually dry up and fall. Spray Mancozeb (2g/liter) or Carbendazim (1g/liter). Remove older, infected leaves from the bottom of the plant to stop the fungus from "climbing" up to the top.

Leaves become thick, leathery, and curl downwards with small "warty" growths (enations) on the underside. Spread by Whiteflies. Control whiteflies immediately and remove infected plants. Avoid planting okra near older, infected hibiscus or cotton plants, as they share the same virus.

The lower leaves turn yellow and the whole plant wilts suddenly, often starting from one side. This is a soil-borne fungus. Drench the soil with Carbendazim (2g/liter). The best prevention is to mix Trichoderma into your compost before planting. Avoid waterlogging, as the fungus moves easily through wet, heavy soil.

Affects young seedlings; the stem at the soil line rots and the plant falls over. Treat seeds with Trichoderma viride (4g/kg) before sowing. Ensure your field has excellent drainage. If you see rot, drench the soil base with Copper Oxychloride (2g/liter). Avoid over-watering the young crop.

The plant looks yellow and stunted; roots have small "knots" or swellings. Plant African Marigold between your okra rows. Apply Neem Cake (250kg/acre) during land preparation. Use the bio-agent Paecilomyces lilacinus in the soil to protect the roots.

A black, powdery layer covers the leaves. This grows on the "honeydew" (sticky liquid) left by Aphids or Mealybugs. To treat, kill the insects using Neem oil or soap spray. Once the insects are gone, the mold will dry up and wash away with water. It blocks the sun from reaching the leaf, reducing fruit yield.

Small, water-soaked spots appear on leaves that later turn brown with a yellow "halo." Spray Streptocycline (1g in 10L) mixed with Copper Oxychloride (2g/liter). This spreads through splashing rain. Avoid working in the field when plants are wet. Use drip irrigation to keep the leaves dry.

A white, "silky" mold grows on the stem just above the soil line, and the plant wilts. You may see small, brown structures like mustard seeds. Drench the base with Copper Oxychloride (3g/liter). Avoid mounding wet soil too high against the stem. Deep summer plowing is very effective in killing the fungus in the soil.

Dark brown circular spots with "target rings" appear on leaves. Spray Mancozeb (2.5g/liter). This usually attacks plants that are weak or lacking nutrition. Ensure balanced fertilization (NPK) to keep the plant's immune system strong. Clean up old crop debris after harvest to stop the fungus from overwintering.

Causes dark, dead-looking (necrotic) streaks on leaves and stems. Spread by Thrips. Control thrips using blue sticky traps and sprays of Neem oil or Fipronil. Since there is no cure for the virus, removing the infected plant is the only way to save the rest of the field.

Large, dark-brown water-soaked patches on leaves during very rainy seasons. It can also rot the pods. Spray Metalaxyl + Mancozeb (2g/liter). Improve drainage immediately so water doesn't stand. Use raised beds for planting to keep the stem base dry.

The green bracts under the flower or the flowers themselves turn brown and rot, preventing fruit from forming. This is caused by high humidity. Spray Carbendazim (1g/liter). Ensure the plants are not too crowded. Avoid overhead sprinklers during the flowering stage.

While not a "disease," it causes leaves to turn yellow and small fruits to fall off. This is often caused by a lack of Micronutrients or sudden temperature changes. Spray a mixture of Micronutrients (2g/liter) and maintain steady soil moisture. Do not let the soil get bone dry and then flood it with water.

Look for purple centers inside water-soaked spots on leaves. Spray Mancozeb (2.5g/liter) or Hexaconazole (2ml/liter). This is the most common onion disease in India. Avoid over-watering and late-season Nitrogen, as it makes leaves too soft. Rotating with Maize or Soybean is highly effective.

Pale yellow patches on leaves with a purplish-white "fuzzy" growth. Spray Metalaxyl + Mancozeb (2g/liter). This happens in cool, humid weather. Avoid overhead irrigation in the evening; morning watering allows the sun to dry the leaves quickly.

Small yellowish spots that grow into large brown, elongated patches. Spray Tebuconazole + Trifloxystrobin (0.5g/liter). This fungus loves high humidity (90%+). Keep the field clean and ensure proper spacing. It often follows Purple Blotch, so treating for one usually helps prevent the other.

Leaves become twisted and elongated like a "snake," and the bulb stays tiny. Spray Propiconazole (1ml/liter). This is soil-borne. Mix Trichoderma viride into your manure before planting. Avoid planting in fields where "Twister" occurred in the last 2 years.

Leaf tips dry out and the bulb base shows white mold with rotting roots. Drench the soil with Carbendazim (2g/liter). Before transplanting, dip seedling roots in Carbendazim solution for 15 minutes. Ensure the field is not waterlogged and use healthy, certified seeds.

Inner scales turn into a mushy, foul-smelling liquid. Spray Streptocycline (1g in 10L) mixed with Copper Oxychloride (2g/liter). Bacteria enter through wounds; avoid damaging bulbs during weeding or harvest. Ensure bulbs are dried (cured) in the shade until the neck is tight.

Diamond-shaped, straw-colored spots on leaves. Spread by Thrips. There is no cure for the virus. Control Thrips using blue sticky traps and sprays of Fipronil (2ml/liter). Remove infected plants immediately to prevent the virus from spreading through the whole crop.

You will see dark, slightly swollen "blisters" on young leaves that eventually burst to reveal black powdery spores. This is a soil-borne disease. Treat seeds with Thiram (3g/kg). Rotate crops for at least 3-4 years. Avoid moving soil from "smut-heavy" fields to clean ones, as the spores can live in the dirt for 15 years.

A thick white "cottony" mold grows at the bulb base with tiny black poppy-seed-like structures. Drench the soil with Tebuconazole. This is a very serious disease. If you see it, do not plant onions or garlic in that field for 5-8 years. Clean all tools thoroughly after working in an infected field.

Roots turn pink, then red, and finally shrivel up. The plant stays small. Thrives in warm weather. Perform soil solarization (covering wet soil with clear plastic for 4-6 weeks in summer) before planting. Use resistant varieties and avoid water stress during the bulb-forming stage.

Black powdery masses appear between the outer scales during storage. Ensure onions are fully cured (dried) until the neck is thin. Store in a cool, dry, dark place with excellent airflow. This fungus loves heat, so keep your storage temperature below 30°C if possible.

The neck becomes soft and sunken in storage, often with a grey mold. This happens if you harvest too early or cut the leaves too close to the bulb. Harvest only when 50-70% of the "necks" have collapsed naturally. Leave 2-3 inches of the neck attached when cutting.

One or two internal scales look "cooked" or water-soaked, and the center can be easily pushed out of the bulb. Spray Copper-based fungicides. This is caused by bacteria splashing into the neck during heavy rain. Ensure excellent drainage and do not use overhead sprinklers during the final month of growth.

Small dark green or black circles appear on the outer scales of white onions. Spray Mancozeb (2g/liter). This is mostly a "cosmetic" disease but lowers market price. Avoid late-season irrigation and ensure bulbs dry quickly after harvest. It is much more common in white onions than red ones.

Leaves show yellow streaks, become crinkled, and droop. Spread by Aphids. No cure exists. Use virus-free sets. Control aphids with yellow sticky traps and Neem oil sprays. Pull out stunted, yellow plants as soon as you see them to save the rest of your harvest.

Small, water-soaked spots with purple centers on leaves. Spray Mancozeb (2.5g/liter) or Azoxystrobin (1ml/liter). Avoid over-watering and late-season Nitrogen. In India, planting by mid-October helps avoid the peak humidity that encourages this fungus.

Pale yellow patches with grey "furry" growth underneath. Leaves eventually collapse. Spray Metalaxyl + Mancozeb (2g/liter). Avoid dense planting to allow morning dew to dry faster. Do not work in the field when leaves are wet to prevent spreading spores.

Yellowish spots that turn into large, elongated brown patches. Spray Tebuconazole (1.5ml/liter) or Mancozeb (2.5g/liter). This fungus loves high humidity. Rotate crops with non-Allium plants (like cereals) for 2–3 years to break the cycle.

Small, orange-to-reddish powdery spots on leaves. Spray Propiconazole (1ml/liter) or Copper Oxychloride (3g/liter). Common in cool, moist conditions. Destroy infected plant debris after harvest to stop the spores from returning next year.

Leaves show patchy green patterns and yellow streaks; bulbs remain very small. Spread by Aphids. No chemical cure exists. Control aphids with yellow sticky traps and Neem oil sprays. Always use virus-free cloves (seeds) and remove infected plants immediately.

Leaf tips turn yellow; the bulb base shows white, fluffy mold and rotted roots. Drench soil with Carbendazim (2g/liter). Before planting, dip garlic cloves in a Carbendazim solution for 15 minutes. Ensure the field is well-drained and not waterlogged.

A white cottony growth with tiny black structures (sclerotia) at the base. No easy cure. If you have this disease, do not grow garlic or onion in that field for 5–8 years. Clean all tools thoroughly after working in an infected field.

Mostly a storage problem; the neck becomes soft and watery with grey mold. Cure (dry) bulbs properly in a shaded, airy place for 10–12 days. Leave 2–3 cm of the neck when cutting; cutting too close to the bulb allows the fungus to enter.

Inner scales turn into a mushy, foul-smelling liquid. Spray Streptocycline (1g in 10L) mixed with Copper Oxychloride (2g/liter). Avoid damaging bulbs during harvest. Bacteria thrive in warm, soggy conditions, so prioritize drainage.

Roots turn pink/red and shrivel. The plant stays stunted. Perform soil solarization (covering wet soil with plastic for 6 weeks in summer) before planting. Long crop rotations (4+ years) and using resistant varieties are the best defenses.

Black powdery masses between outer scales, usually in storage. Happens when temperatures exceed 30°C. Ensure garlic is fully dried before storage. Store in a cool, dark, well-ventilated place and avoid bruising the bulbs.

Clues are a blue-green powdery mold on the cloves. It often starts in the field but gets worse in storage. Treat cloves with Carbendazim before planting. Avoid harvesting in wet weather and ensure bulbs are dried quickly and kept at low humidity during storage.

Small dark green or black circles on the outer scales of the bulb. Spray Mancozeb (2g/liter). This is mostly a cosmetic disease but lowers the market price. Avoid late-season irrigation and ensure bulbs dry quickly after harvest.

Small, dark, "sooty" spots or streaks on the outer skin. Usually doesn't rot the clove but makes it look dirty. Ensure proper curing and storage. If it appears in the field, spray Mancozeb. It is more common in white garlic varieties than purple-skinned ones.

Cloves turn yellow, translucent, and waxy, then eventually dark brown. This is NOT caused by a germ but by high temperatures during the final growth stage or in storage. Ensure your storage area is well-ventilated and kept below 25°C. Avoid exposing harvested bulbs to direct, scorching sun for long periods.

Diamond-shaped, straw-colored spots on leaves. Spread by Thrips. No cure for the virus. Control Thrips using blue sticky traps and sprays of Fipronil (2ml/liter). Pull out infected plants as soon as you see them.

The most devastating ginger disease. Leaves turn yellow and the base becomes watery; the ginger turns into a mushy, foul-smelling mass. Treatment: Drench soil with Metalaxyl + Mancozeb (2g/liter). Prevention: Always use 30cm high raised beds for drainage. Never plant ginger in a field where rot occurred last year.

Leaves suddenly droop and turn yellow. A "milky white thread" oozes from the stem when put in water. Treatment: No chemical cure; pull out and burn infected plants. Prevention: Dip seed rhizomes in Streptocycline (1g in 10L) for 30 minutes before planting.

Leaves turn pale yellow and curl. The ginger doesn't turn mushy but shows brown rings inside when cut. Treatment: Drench the base with Carbendazim (2g/liter). Prevention: Mix Trichoderma viride (2kg/acre) with manure before planting to kill the wilt fungus in the soil.

Small, oval spots with white centers and dark brown margins. If severe, leaves dry up. Treatment: Spray Mancozeb (2.5g/liter) or Carbendazim (1g/liter) at 15-day intervals. Proper spacing allows sunlight to reach lower leaves and kill spores.

Similar to regular leaf spot but spots are larger and create "shot holes" in the leaves. Treatment: Spray Copper Oxychloride (3g/liter). Remove and burn old, spotted leaves to stop spores from splashing onto new growth during rain.

White, thread-like growth on the leaf underside causes leaves to wither and hang. Treatment: Spray Bordeaux Mixture (1%). Common in shaded, humid areas. Prune nearby trees to let in more sunlight and improve air circulation.

Ginger rots after harvest in storage. Treatment: Before storing, treat rhizomes with Mancozeb (3g/liter) for 30 minutes and dry in the shade. Store in cool, well-ventilated pits. Avoid stacking ginger too high to prevent heat build-up.

Small "warts" or galls on the ginger skin; plant looks yellow and weak. Treatment: Apply Neem Cake (400kg/acre) during land preparation. Prevention: Plant African Marigold as a border crop and use the bio-agent Paecilomyces lilacinus.

Tiny grey scales make the ginger look "shriveled" and create wounds for rot. Treatment: Dip seed rhizomes in Quinalphos (2ml/liter) before planting. This keeps the skin healthy and prevents germs from entering.

Leaves become thick, small, and show yellow mottling. Treatment: No cure; pull out infected plants immediately. Prevention: Control insects (Aphids/Thrips) using Neem Oil (5ml/liter). Use only certified healthy seed ginger.

Caused by Diplodia, making the ginger light, dry, and corky. Treatment: Avoid wounding ginger during harvest. Treat with Propiconazole (1ml/liter) before storage. Do not dry ginger in direct hot sun, as cracks allow fungus in.
Tiny black dots appear in a circular pattern on leaf spots. Treatment: Spray Mancozeb (2g/liter). Keep the field and bunds clean of all grass and weeds, as the fungus survives on weed hosts.

The stem at the soil line turns brown and rots, causing the plant to fall. Treatment: Drench with Copper Oxychloride (3g/liter). Avoid mounding too much wet soil against the stem. Ensure the soil is not too acidic by adding Lime (Chuna).

Greyish-white spots with a thin purple border. Usually appears in the late monsoon. Treatment: Spray Zineb (2g/liter). This fungus survives on old crop residue; always clean the field thoroughly after the final harvest.

A white, mushroom-like "fan" of fungus grows under the skin of the rhizome. Usually occurs in newly cleared forest land. Treatment: No chemical fix. Remove the infected clump and the soil around it. Avoid planting ginger in land where old tree roots are still decaying.

Bright yellow streaks run parallel to the veins. Spread by mechanical contact or tools. Treatment: No cure. Wash tools with a mild bleach solution after working with a sick plant. Use only tissue-culture or guaranteed virus-free seeds.

White flour-like patches on leaves. Spray Hexaconazole (2ml/liter) or wettable Sulfur (3g/liter). For an organic fix, use a baking soda spray (5g/liter). Avoid overcrowding to let sunlight reach the inner leaves.

Yellow angular patches on top with grey "fuzz" underneath. Spray Metalaxyl + Mancozeb (2g/liter). Avoid overhead watering; drip irrigation is best. Ensure proper spacing to help leaves dry quickly after rain.

Water-soaked spots that ooze a reddish-brown "gum" from stems. Spray Thiophanate Methyl (1g/liter) or Mancozeb (2.5g/liter). Always use certified seeds and clean up all crop debris after harvest to stop the fungus from hiding in old vines.

Leaf veins turn bright yellow; leaves become small/deformed. Spread by Whiteflies. No cure—pull out and bury sick plants immediately. Control whiteflies with yellow sticky traps and sprays of Imidacloprid (0.5ml/liter) or Neem oil.

Sunken dark spots on leaves and fruit. Spray Carbendazim (1g/liter) or Mancozeb (2g/liter). Treat seeds with Thiram (3g/kg). Avoid working in the field when leaves are wet to prevent the spread of spores on tools.
Small water-soaked "square" spots that may fall out, leaving "shot holes." Spray Streptocycline (1g in 10L) mixed with Copper Oxychloride (2g/liter). Rotate crops with non-cucurbits for 2–3 years.
Small brown spots with "target-like" rings. Spray Mancozeb (2.5g/liter). Plants lacking Potassium (Potash) are more vulnerable. Deep summer plowing helps kill spores hiding in the soil.

Whole plant wilts suddenly during the hot day. Drench the base with Carbendazim (2g/liter). Mix Trichoderma viride (2kg/acre) into your manure before planting. Improve drainage to prevent standing water.
Fruit touching wet soil turns soft with white "yeast-like" growth. Spray Metalaxyl (2g/liter). Grow pumpkins on mulch or raised beds. Remove and bury rotted fruits far away from the field.
Stunted/yellow plants; roots have small round "knots." Plant African Marigold as a border crop. Apply Neem Cake (250kg/acre) during land preparation. Use the bio-agent Paecilomyces lilacinus.
Small sunken spots on fruit that ooze a greenish-brown fluid. Spray Chlorothalonil (2g/liter). This loves cool, moist weather. Use disease-free seeds and avoid overhead irrigation.

Leaves look "bumpy," mottled green, and fruits are deformed with "warts." Spread by Aphids. No cure. Control aphids using yellow sticky traps and Neem oil. Keep the field free of weeds like milkweed which act as hosts.

The side of the pumpkin touching the ground turns brown and dry/corky. This happens in very hot, humid weather. Use plastic mulch or a thick layer of dry straw to keep the pumpkin from touching the soil.

A white "cottony" growth appears on stems or fruit, often with hard black "seeds" (sclerotia). Spray Carbendazim (1g/liter). This fungus survives in the soil for years. Rotate with non-susceptible crops like corn or wheat.

The bottom of the fruit (where the flower was) turns black and leathery. This is a Calcium deficiency caused by uneven watering. Maintain consistent soil moisture and apply Lime (Chuna) or a Calcium spray during fruit setting.

Flowers and young fruits are covered in "black-headed whiskers" and rot quickly. Spray Copper Oxychloride (3g/liter). This is very common during heavy monsoon rains. Removing spent flowers can help reduce the chance of rot.

Raised white, "chalky" blisters on leaf undersides and yellow patches on top. Spray Metalaxyl + Mancozeb (2g/liter). Avoid overhead watering. Remove infected plants immediately to prevent the "white dust" spores from spreading.

Dark brown/black spots with "target rings" on leaves. Spray Mancozeb (2.5g/liter). This fungus loves high humidity. Ensure proper spacing and burn old plant debris after harvest to stop the fungus from hiding in the soil.

Pale yellow patches on top with grey/purple "fuzz" underneath. Spray Metalaxyl (2g/liter). Common in cool, damp weather. Use raised beds for drainage and avoid planting too early in the winter when dew is heavy.
Circular spots with grey centers and reddish-brown borders. Spray Carbendazim (1g/liter). Thrives in hot, humid weather. Removing older, infected bottom leaves helps reduce the spread.

Yellow "V-shaped" patches on leaf edges; veins turn black. Spray Streptocycline (1g in 10L) mixed with Copper Oxychloride (2g/liter). Use hot-water treated seeds (50°C for 30 mins) and avoid working in wet fields.
Leaves look "mosaic" (patchy green) and wrinkled. Spread by Aphids. No chemical cure. Control aphids with yellow sticky traps and Neem oil sprays. Pull out and bury infected plants immediately.

Leaves yellow on one side; plant wilts. Root shows a brown ring inside. Drench base with Carbendazim (2g/liter). Mix Trichoderma viride into compost before planting. Ensure soil is not too acidic (add Lime if needed).
Seedlings rot at the soil line and fall over. Treat seeds with Trichoderma (10g/kg) before sowing. Use raised beds and drench soil with Copper Oxychloride (2g/liter) if rot appears.
Raised, "corky" or warty brown patches on radish skin. Common in dry, alkaline soils. Keep soil consistently moist during the first 4 weeks. Avoid adding fresh manure right before planting.
Plant wilts during the day; roots are swollen and deformed like "clubs." No easy cure. Increase soil pH by adding Lime (Chuna). Avoid planting radish in the same spot for at least 3 years.

Sunken, brown, dry lesions appear on the root near the soil line. Spray Thiophanate Methyl (1g/liter). Avoid deep planting and ensure the soil is well-aerated. Deep summer plowing is very effective in killing the fungus.

The root turns black, particularly at the point where side roots emerge. Caused by Aphanomyces. Spray Fenamidone + Mancozeb. This loves waterlogged, heavy soils. Improve drainage and rotate with non-cruciferous crops.

The root turns into a mushy, foul-smelling liquid. Usually starts from wounds. Avoid wounding roots during weeding. Ensure the field has no standing water. Spray Copper Oxychloride (3g/liter) around the base.

The flowers turn into green leaf-like structures, and the plant becomes bushy. Spread by Leafhoppers. No cure. Control leafhoppers with Neem oil or Dimethoate. Pull out and destroy infected plants immediately.
While not a "disease," it causes internal browning or "brown heart" and cracked roots. Spray Borax (2g/liter) during the mid-growth stage. Common in sandy or over-limed soils.
Stunted/yellow plants; roots have "knots" or look hairy. Plant African Marigold as a border crop. Apply Neem Cake (250kg/acre) during land preparation.

Yellow angular spots on top of leaves with grey "fuzz" underneath. Spray Metalaxyl + Mancozeb (2g/liter). Avoid overhead watering. Growing vines on a Mandap (trellis) is the best way to keep leaves dry and stop the spread.

White, flour-like patches on both sides of the leaf. Spray Hexaconazole (2ml/liter) or wettable Sulfur (3g/liter). A home remedy of baking soda (5g/liter) also works. Avoid over-using Nitrogen, which makes leaves soft and easy to infect.

Patchy yellow patterns on wrinkled leaves; plant stays stunted. Spread by Whiteflies. No cure—pull out sick plants immediately. Control whiteflies with yellow sticky traps and sprays of Imidacloprid (0.5ml/liter) or Neem oil.

Leaves look "mottled" (mixed light/dark green) and distorted. Spread by Aphids. No chemical cure. Kill aphids using Neem oil or yellow sticky traps. Keep field borders free of weeds where aphids and the virus hide.

Leaves turn yellow from the bottom up, and the whole vine wilts suddenly. Drench the base with Carbendazim (2g/liter). Mix Trichoderma viride into your manure before planting. Use raised beds to prevent waterlogging.

Water-soaked yellow spots on leaves and sunken black spots on fruit. Spray Carbendazim (1g/liter). Treat seeds with Thiram (3g/kg). Avoid working in the field when leaves are wet to prevent the spread of spores.

Small circular spots with grey centers and dark margins. Spray Mancozeb (2g/liter). This loves high humidity. Pruning older bottom leaves improves airflow. Ensure the trellis is high enough to keep leaves off the soil.
Seedlings in the nursery rot at the soil line and fall over. Treat seeds with Trichoderma (10g/kg) before sowing. Use raised beds and drench soil with Copper Oxychloride (2g/liter) if rot appears.

Fruit touching wet ground develops white "cottony" growth and rots. Spray Metalaxyl (2g/liter). The most effective fix is using a Trellis system so fruit never touches the soil. Bury rotted fruits far away.
Small, water-soaked "square" spots that may fall out, leaving "shot holes." Spray Streptocycline (1g in 10L) mixed with Copper Oxychloride (2g/liter). Rotate crops with non-gourds for 2 years.
Small sunken spots on fruit that ooze greenish fluid; also causes "shot holes" in leaves. Spray Chlorothalonil (2g/liter). Loves cool, moist nights. Avoid planting too early in winter.
Water-soaked spots on leaves and stems that ooze reddish-brown "gum." Spray Thiophanate Methyl (1g/liter). Use healthy, certified seeds and remove all old vines after harvest.
The side of the fruit touching the ground turns brown and corky. This happens in hot, humid weather. Use a trellis or place dry straw/mulch under fruits if they must grow on the ground.

Flowers and young fruits are covered in "black-headed whiskers" and rot quickly. Spray Copper Oxychloride (3g/liter). Very common during heavy monsoon. Removing spent flowers helps reduce the chance of rot.
Small brown spots with "target-like" rings. Spray Mancozeb (2.5g/liter). Usually attacks plants with poor nutrition. Ensure balanced NPK fertilizer to keep the vine's immune system strong.
Stunted/yellow plants; roots have small round "knots." Plant African Marigold as a border crop. Apply Neem Cake (250kg/acre) during land preparation.
Yellow irregular spots on top; purplish-grey "fuzz" underneath. Spray Metalaxyl + Mancozeb (2g/liter). Avoid evening watering; leaves must be dry at night. Use wider spacing for air circulation.
Small circular spots with white/grey centers and dark reddish borders. Spray Carbendazim (1g/liter) or Mancozeb (2g/liter). Removing older bottom leaves stops the fungus from jumping to new growth.
Small water-soaked spots that turn brown and thin like paper. Spray Copper Oxychloride (3g/liter). Ensure good drainage to prevent soil splashing onto leaves. Use healthy, disease-free seeds.
Young seedlings rot at the base and fall over. Treat seeds with Trichoderma viride (4g/kg) before sowing. Drench soil with Copper Oxychloride (2g/liter) if rot appears. Use raised beds.

Leaves turn yellow; the whole plant wilts. Roots look dark or rotted. Soil-borne. Drench with Carbendazim (2g/liter). Best fix: mix Trichoderma into compost before planting. Rotate crops every 2-3 years.
Patchy green/yellow "mosaic" patterns; wrinkled leaves. Spread by Aphids. No cure. Control aphids with yellow sticky traps and Neem oil (5ml/liter). Pull out and bury infected plants immediately.
White "chalky" blisters on the leaf underside. Spray Metalaxyl (2g/liter). If seen, harvest healthy leaves immediately and destroy infected ones. Avoid overhead sprinklers.
Grey-to-tan circular spots that make leaves look "burnt." Spray Propiconazole (1ml/liter). Often confused with heat stress. Ensure plants have enough Potassium to strengthen leaf edges.
Small, water-soaked greasy spots that turn brown. Spray Streptocycline (1g in 10L) mixed with Copper Oxychloride (2g/liter). Avoid high-pressure sprays that wound the leaf skin.
Small, round, dark green "fuzzy" spots on both sides of the leaf. Spray Mancozeb (2.5g/liter). Happens in cool, wet conditions. Never harvest when plants are wet.
Roots turn black and "slimy," and the plant stays stunted. Drench soil with Metalaxyl (2g/liter). This loves waterlogged soil. Improve drainage and avoid over-irrigating during the monsoon.
Small brown spots that develop tiny black dots in the center. Spray Copper Oxychloride (3g/liter). Clean up all crop residue after harvest as the fungus hides in dead leaves.
Large, dark, mushy patches on leaves during very heavy rain. Spray Mancozeb. Best managed by using a temporary plastic rain shelter over the crop during peak monsoon.

One side of the leaf or plant turns yellow and wilts. Soil-borne. There is no chemical cure. Avoid planting in soil where potatoes or tomatoes were recently grown. Use Trichoderma at the time of sowing.
The edges of the leaves turn brown and dry. This is a Calcium deficiency caused by high heat or irregular watering. Maintain steady moisture and spray a Calcium-based micronutrient if needed.

New leaves are bright yellow, but the veins stay dark green. Spray Ferrous Sulfate (2g/liter). Common in alkaline (high pH) soils. Adding organic manure helps lower the pH and release Iron to the plant.

Yellow angular patches on top; purple-grey "fuzz" underneath. Spray Metalaxyl + Mancozeb (2g/liter). Using a Trellis (Pandal) is essential. Avoid watering in the late evening so leaves don't stay wet overnight.
Green/yellow mottling and wrinkled leaves; twisted fruits. Spread by Aphids. No cure. Control aphids with yellow sticky traps and Neem oil (5ml/liter). Pull out and bury infected vines immediately.

White flour-like patches on leaves. Spray Hexaconazole (2ml/liter) or wettable Sulfur (3g/liter). Ensure the vine is not overcrowded; air must flow through the leaves to prevent this fungus from settling.
Water-soaked spots on stems that ooze reddish-brown "gum." Spray Thiophanate Methyl (1g/liter). Avoid wounding stems during weeding. Clean up old crop debris after harvest to kill hiding spores.
Sunken black spots on fruit and leaves. Spray Carbendazim (1g/liter). Treat seeds with Thiram (3g/kg) before sowing. Avoid touching vines when they are wet with rain or dew.
Vine wilts suddenly; "milky thread" oozes from cut stems in water. No cure. Control Cucumber Beetles using Neem-based insecticides. Rotate with non-gourd crops like Corn or Millet.
Tips of long gourds turn soft and rot. Spray Metalaxyl (2g/liter). Ensure the Pandal is 6-7 feet high so gourds hang freely. Remove and bury rotted fruits far from the field.
Small circular spots with grey centers and purple borders. Spray Mancozeb (2g/liter). Pruning older, lower leaves improves sunlight penetration and reduces moisture.
Leaves yellow from base; plant wilts in the heat. Soil-borne. Drench base with Carbendazim (2g/liter). Mix Trichoderma viride into manure at planting time.
Weak/yellow vines; roots have "knots." Apply Neem Cake (250kg/acre) during land preparation. Planting Marigolds at the base of the trellis helps kill these worms.
Flowers and young fruits covered in "black-headed whiskers." Spray Copper Oxychloride (3g/liter). Common in heavy rain. Removing dead flowers from the tips of young fruits can stop the rot.

The lower stem turns dark brown or black and the plant wilts. Tiny black dots appear under the bark. Drench with Carbendazim. This loves hot, dry soil followed by heavy rain. Use mulch to keep soil temperature steady.
Causes severe "bumpy" distorted fruit and extreme yellowing. Spread by Aphids. No cure. This is more aggressive than common mosaic. Maintain strict aphid control from day one of planting.
The vine rots right at the soil level, often showing white "silk-like" fungal threads. Drench with Copper Oxychloride (3g/liter). Avoid mounding wet soil directly against the main stem.

The tip of the fruit turns black and leathery (without mushy rot). This is a Calcium deficiency caused by irregular watering. Ensure steady moisture and spray Calcium Nitrate (5g/liter) during fruit formation.

Long gourds split open on the sides. Usually caused by heavy rain or sudden heavy irrigation after a dry spell. Maintain consistent soil moisture. Avoid heavy Nitrogen doses during the peak fruiting stage.

Unlike common mosaic, this causes "mottled" green patches and can be carried inside the seed. Plants look healthy at first but suddenly produce small, tasteless fruit with dark green "splotches." Treatment: No cure. Pull out plants immediately. Prevention: Only buy certified "Virus-Free" seeds. Soak seeds in a 10% solution of Tri-sodium Phosphate (TSP) for 20 minutes if you suspect seed contamination.

Mostly seen in Northern India (Delhi/Haryana). Plants are severely stunted with very small, curly, yellow leaves. Spread by Whiteflies. Treatment: No cure. Control whiteflies with yellow sticky traps and Acetamiprid (0.2g/liter). Removing the weeds around the field is vital, as this virus hides in wild grasses during the off-season.

A thick, white, "fan-shaped" mold grows on the soil and stem base. You will see small, round, brown balls (like mustard seeds) in the mold. Treatment: Drench the soil with Hexaconazole (2ml/liter) or Tebuconazole. This fungus stays in the soil for years. Rotate with non-susceptible crops like Rice or Wheat. Solarize your soil in summer with plastic sheets to kill the "seeds."

The whole vine develops large, dark, "greasy" water-soaked patches and collapses overnight during heavy monsoons. Treatment: Spray Metalaxyl + Mancozeb (2g/liter) or Cymoxanil (2g/liter). This is a "water mold." Ensure your raised beds are at least 1 foot high and that water never touches the main stem "collar" of the plant.

Old leaves turn light green or yellow, starting from the tips. The whole plant looks "pale." Treatment: Apply Urea or Ammonium Nitrate to the soil. For a quick fix, use a foliar spray of 1% Urea (10g in 1L water). This is often mistaken for a virus; if the veins stay green, it is usually a nutrient issue, not a germ.

Fruits become crooked, deformed, and the skin looks "corky" or cracked. The growing tips of the vine may also die back. Treatment: Spray Borax (2g/liter) or Solubor once during the start of flowering. This is very common in sandy soils or after heavy rain that washes nutrients away.

The bottom of the gourd (where the flower was) turns black, dry, and leathery. Treatment: This is caused by Calcium deficiency linked to irregular watering. Maintain a steady water schedule (don't let the soil go from bone-dry to flooded). Spray Calcium Nitrate (5g/liter) on the young fruits.

Small circular grey spots on leaves and soft, light-brown sunken rot on the fruit. Treatment: Spray Carbendazim (1g/liter). This is very similar to Anthracnose but has tiny black dots in the center of the spots. Avoid overhead sprinklers; use drip irrigation to keep the fruit and leaves dry.

Similar to Okra, the veins turn bright yellow while the rest of the leaf remains green. Spread by Whiteflies. Treatment: No cure. Pull out infected plants. Prevention: Install yellow sticky traps (15/acre) and spray Neem Oil (5ml/liter) or Acetamiprid early in the morning to kill whiteflies.

A thick white mold grows around the base of the stem at the soil line. You will see small, round, brown structures (sclerotia) that look like mustard seeds. Treatment: Drench the base with Hexaconazole (2ml/liter). This fungus loves high humidity and heavy manure. Ensure the soil around the stem is well-aerated.

The plant produces many tiny, crowded leaves instead of normal vines, looking like a "broom." Spread by Leafhoppers. Treatment: No cure. Pull out and destroy the plant. Prevention: Control leafhoppers using Dimethoate (2ml/liter). Keeping the field free of wild weeds like Parthenium (Congress grass) is vital as they harbor the phytoplasma.

The stem turns black and mushy, especially near the joints (nodes). This usually happens during the height of the rainy season. Treatment: Spray Carbendazim + Mancozeb (2g/liter). Avoid over-application of Urea, which makes the stems soft and juicy, attracting this fungus.

A black, powdery layer covers the leaves. This is not a direct disease but a fungus growing on the sticky "honeydew" left by Aphids or Mealybugs. Treatment: Kill the insects first. Once the insects are gone, the mold will dry up and wash off with water. The mold hurts the plant by blocking sunlight.

The roots and lower stem turn dark brown, and the bark can be easily peeled off to reveal tiny black specks. The plant wilts suddenly. Treatment: Drench the soil with Carbendazim (2g/liter). This disease thrives in "heat stress"—when the soil is very hot and dry, then suddenly becomes wet. Mulching helps keep soil temperatures steady.

The flowers turn yellow and fall off before fruit can form. Treatment: This is often caused by a lack of Micronutrients or very high temperatures. Spray a Micronutrient Mix (2g/liter) containing Boron and Zinc. Also, ensure there are enough bees in the field for pollination; avoid spraying pesticides during the daytime when bees are active.

The sponge gourd develops a very bitter taste. Treatment: This is caused by high levels of "Cucurbitacins," triggered by drought stress or sudden high heat. Maintain a consistent watering schedule and ensure the soil is rich in organic matter to buffer the plant against heat.
